Title: Ex-U.S. stars turn out to honor Morgan in Philly
Description:
Alex Morgan reacts to her first goal for the USWNT in a friendly vs. China. (1:15)

CHESTER, Pa. -- Everywhere fans turned on Thursday at Subaru Park, there were reminders of Alex Morgan's illustrious United States national team career, from the eponymous pink pre-wrap headband station outside the gates to a Morgan bobblehead handed out to the first couple thousand fans through the gate.

U.S. Soccer honored the career of Morgan on Thursday as the USWNT faced Portugal at the same stadium where Morgan scored the first of her 123 international goals, which ranks fifth in program history. She scored her first goal in the same stadium in 2010.

Morgan retired last year as a two-time World Cup champion and Olympic gold medalist.

"You can't go anywhere in this country without them talking about Alex Morgan, and I think the sport should show a lot of gratitude to that, because it's important for our players to be recognizable," USWNT head coach Emma Hayes said the day before the match. "She is, without question, in recent times, one of the most recognizable faces in our sport."

Former teammates Abby Wambach, Megan Rapinoe, Ali Krieger and Kelley O'Hara were among those in attendance for Morgan's ceremony before the match. Forward Trinity Rodman, who missed this training camp due to a sprained MCL, was also in attendance on the sideline before the match to support Morgan.

U.S. Soccer president Cindy Parlow Cone and federation CEO JT Batson presented Morgan, flanked by her family, with flowers and a framed jersey with the No. 224, representing her number of appearances for the team.

"There was nothing she didn't achieve," Hayes said. "She was a player that epitomized everything that this program is about. She's an unbelievable credit to her family, because her drive, her desire, her determination to prove herself at the highest level is second to none."

Prior to the match, the videoboard in the stadium ran a recording of current, younger USWNT players answering trivia about Morgan's career before sharing what the former forward meant to them and the team.

"She has meant so much to me and the game," USWNT forward Alyssa Thompson said Wednesday before practice at Subaru Park. "She's made the game better. I feel like I wouldn't be in the position I'm in right now if it weren't for the players that came before me -- especially Alex -- and them fighting for equality and equal pay.

"I just want to continue her legacy, but thinking about what she did on the field is something that can't be replicated, which is really cool."

Last month, the San Diego Wave retired Morgan's No. 13 jersey. Morgan ended her club career there and made San Diego a home for her family. She became a minority investor in the Wave earlier this year.

A second video tribute to Morgan at halftime Thursday ended with her daughter, Charlie, saying, "Good night, we out."

Despite the celebrations in honor of Morgan, Portugal pulled off a surprise win over the U.S., coming back from a goal down to win 2-1.

Title: U-17 WNT Wins Group C with Dominant Win over Norway in 2025 FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup
Description:
Get unrivaled matchday access

SAL√â, Morocco (Oct. 24, 2025) -- The U.S Under-17 Women's National Team defeated Norway 5-0 to win Group C at the 2025 FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup. It was the second time the USA has won its group at this tournament (with 2022 in India being the other) but the first time the U.S. U-17s have won all three group games. 

Three National Women's Soccer League players scored goals as forwards KK Ream (Utah Royals), Ellie Kocher and Micayla Johnson (Chicago Stars) and midfielder Mak Whitham (Gotham FC) each tallied their first goals of the tournament while Nyanya Touray came off the bench to score her fourth.

The USA will now face the third-place team from Group A, B or F on Tuesday, Oct. 28 at 11:30 a.m. ET on FS2.

The USA has scored 13 goals in group play in this tournament, matching its record for most goals during the group stage at the FIFA U-17 WWC, which was set in India in 2022, but that group stage included an 8-0 win over India.

U.S. head coach Katie Schoepfer made six changes to the starting XI from the second group match, a 5-2 win over China PR that clinched a berth in the Round of 16 with one match -- this one against Norway -- remaining. Schoepfer kept the same back line and changed five of the six midfielders/forwards, and the USA scored five goals in a game for the second time in the tournament.

Goalkeeper Peyton Trayer got the nod in the nets for the USA after Evan O'Steen had started the first two matches. Trayer earned her first World Cup shutout. 

Norway, needing a win to have any chance of advancing in a tournament that sends four third-place teams to the knockout round, fell far short. It took the USA just under six minutes to score as Ream dribbled into the left side of the penalty area, made a bit of space for herself to shoot and smacked her left-footed shot off the right post and in from 16 yards out. For Ream, the youngest goal scorer in NWSL history when she tallied on Aug. 29 for the Utah Royals at 16 years and 52 days old, it was her first goal of this tournament. It was also the USA's fastest goal yet of the tournament.

The USA doubled its lead in the 49th minute and effectively put the game away as the young Americans were even more dominant in the second half. Midfielder Scottie Antonucci played a ball to Kocher just above the penalty box on the right. Kocher beat Norway defender Lea Ellingsen with a quick cut to her right as she dribbled into the penalty area and then struck her shot on the ground inside the left post from just above the corner of the six-yard box. It was Kocher's first goal of the tournament as well.

Midfielder Nyanya Touray entered the match in the 61st minute and made an immediate impact, scoring in the 63rd. The goal came as Ream got around the defense into the left side of the penalty area and cut a pass back to Touray, who perfectly timed her run and finished with the inside of her right foot from 10 yards out. The goal momentarily tied Touray for the lead in the Golden Boot race with four goals so far in the tournament, and she of course leads the USA in scoring.

The USA made it two goals in a two-minute span when a nice attack down the right side saw Johnson, who came on in the 62nd minute, cross from the right side to Ream, who sent a header on goal. Norway goalkeeper Sara Holte, who came on at halftime, saved the shot but spilled the ball right at the feet of Whitham, who smashed the rebound into the net from close range to make it 4-0 in the 64th.

The USA finished the scoring in the 80th minute and this time it was Johnson. She played a give-and-go with substitute Lauren Malsom in the right side of the penalty box and then rolled her shot off the left post and in from about 16 yards out.

Trayer was called into action in the 30th minute as Norway forward Christina Herseth got behind the U.S. defense into the left side of the penalty area drove a high shot at goal. Trayer pushed the ball away, but the rebound fell to another Norway attacker and Trayer had to save that shot with a dive to her left.

The USA utilized the Video Support System in the 38th minute, asking for a penalty kick review as Celia Halvorsen bundled into outside back Sydney Schmidt in the right side of the penalty area as both battled for a cross. After video review, the referee denied the request.

Whitham had two good chances to score inside the final five minutes of the first half. In the 42nd minute she intercepted a back pass deep inside the penalty box, but she was in close quarters with the Norway goalkeeper Maria Kroken, who stole the ball off her feet. In the 45th minute, Schmidt made a great dribbling run, advanced the ball 40 yards down the left side and played Ream on the wing. Ream crossed to Whitham inside the six-yard box, but the USA's youngest player at 15 years of age put her close range shot over the bar. Whitham would get her goal later in the game.

Norway exited its first FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup without scoring a goal.

USA ‚Äì KK Ream, 6th minute: The USA benefited from a Norway turnover in the back as Ream dribbled in the left channel and struck a left-footed shot from just inside the penalty area off the right post and in past the diving Norway goalkeeper. USA 1, NOR 0

USA ‚Äì Ellie Kocher (Scottie Antonucci), 49th minute: Antonucci played a short pass to Kocher just above the penalty box on the right. She took on her defender one-on-one, scorched her to the outside, and then drove her shot on the ground inside the left post from just above the corner of the six-yard box. USA 2, NOR 0

USA ‚Äì Nyanya Touray (KK Ream), 63rd minute: Touray immediately sparked the USA after coming off the bench, scoring seconds after subbing on. Touray ran onto a perfect cut back pass into the seam from Ream and finished with the inside of her right foot from 10 yards. USA 3, NOR 0

USA ‚Äì Mak Whitham, 64th minute: Whitham capitalized on a mistake from the Norway goalkeeper who dropped KK Ream's header just in front of the goal and the 15-year-old made her pay, blasting the ball into the net from close range. USA 4, NOR 0

USA ‚Äì Micayla Johnson, 80th minute: Johnson and fellow sub Lauren Malsom played a give-and-go in the right side of the box which set up Johnson to roll her shot off the left post and in from about 16 yards out and become the first American player to score in two FIFA U-17 Women's World Cups. USA 5, NOR 0 ‚Äì FINAL

Match: United States Under-17 Women's National Team vs. Norway

Competition: 2025 FIFA Under-17 Women's World Cup ‚Äì Group C 

Venue: Mohammed VI Football Academy (Pitch 3); Sal√©, Morocco

Attendance: 500

Kickoff: Noon local (9 a.m. ET)

Title: US women's soccer team loses to Portugal for first time
Description:
CHESTER, Pa. ‚Äî The U.S. women's soccer team stumbled Thursday in its first game since July, allowing a goal in each half that sent Portugal to its first win against the Americans, 2-1, on the same night two-time Women's World Cup winner Alex Morgan was feted with a star-studded farewell.

Portugal not only beat the Americans for the first time in 12 matches, it scored its first goals against them in international play.

U.S. coach Emma Hayes said she could tell at practice ahead of the match the nearly four-month layoff could affect her team.

"It felt to me like we just hadn't played together for a long time," Hayes said. "I just didn't recognize us."

Rose Lavelle scored only 33 seconds into the exhibition match for the hosts, only for Portugal goalkeeper Ines Pereira to shut the Americans down the rest of the game.

Lavelle electrified the crowd at Subaru Park, the home field for Major League Soccer's Philadelphia Union, when she scored before many of the more than 17,000 fans had even settled into their seats after a pregame ceremony for Morgan.

"Sometimes you can start the game like that and you think to yourself, 'I hope we don't sit back and be passive,'" Hayes said. "That's what we did."

Portugal's Diana Gomes scored her eighth international goal when she got a header past Phallon Tullis-Joyce that tied the game in the first half. Portugal had been outscored 40-0 by the United States in the previous 11 matches between the teams, plus Lavelle's goal.

Fatima Pinto scored her fifth international goal from atop the box through traffic late in the second half for the winner that gave Portugal its landmark victory.

"There is a standard of winning, and it kind of exceeds all those things, whether it's the time apart or the age of the team or experience. We have a choice now of how we respond," U.S. midfielder Sam Coffey said.

The U.S. team returned after a 113-day layoff for the start of a true ramp-up toward Women's World Cup qualifications. There's another match scheduled against Portugal and one against New Zealand to close out the three-match window at the end of the month.

The team needs the work before the results truly matter.

"We didn't look like the team that we've been working on, but that's what happens when you've got 113 days apart," Hayes said.

With the 36-year-old Morgan in the house, the stadium underwent a makeover in honor of her big night.

Her greatest moments (such as her four-goal game for the U20 women's World Cup team) were recognized in stand-up cutouts that lined the outside of the stadium. Girls lined up at the pre-wrap station to get their hair game-day ready, and T-shirts and banners with Morgan's name on them were the hot items for sale. Fans everywhere raised signs showing the former striker love in her national team send-off.

Even national team members who couldn't take the field wouldn't miss the big night for Morgan, who retired from soccer last year when she became pregnant with her second child.

American forward Trinity Rodman was on hand for Morgan's celebration but did not play as she recovers from a knee injury. Rodman has played for the Americans just once since they won a gold medal at the 2024 Paris Olympics. Retired U.S. players Kelley O'Hara, Megan Rapinoe and Abby Wambach also attended the game.

Besides being part of Women's World Cup championship teams in 2015 and 2019, Morgan also won an Olympic gold medal in 2012. She played in 224 matches for the U.S. ‚Äî and was honored with a framed jersey with that total as the number ‚Äî with 123 goals and 53 assists. She was chosen the U.S. women's soccer player of the year in 2012 and 2018.

Morgan also played in 150 National Women's Soccer League matches during her professional career, spending time with the Portland Thorns, Orlando Pride and San Diego Wave. She rejoined the San Diego Wave in May as a minority stakeholder.

Hayes only had Morgan for one game during her tenure, but the former Chelsea coach has been around the sport long enough to appreciate the American great's impact on the game ‚Äî and for her to be feted at the same stadium where she scored her first national team goal in 2010.

"There was nothing she didn't achieve," Hayes said a day earlier. "She was a player that epitomized everything this program is about. She's an unbelievable credit to her family because her drive, her desire, her determination to prove herself at the highest level is second to none.

"You can't go anywhere in this country without them talking about Alex Morgan, and I think the sport should show a lot of gratitude to that, because it's important for our players to be recognizable. And she is, without question, in recent times, one of the most recognizable faces in our sport."

Title: Inside the US Women's National Soccer Team match against Portugal in Chester
Description:
The US Women's National Soccer Team played a friendly match against Portugal at Subaru Park in Chester and fans were thrilled to see their soccer heroes, including Alex Morgan.

CHESTER, Pa. - Soccer fans had a night to remember as the US Women's National Team faced off against Portugal at Subaru Park. 

The event was a celebration of women's soccer, drawing in families and young fans eager to see their idols in action. 

The atmosphere was electric, with many young girls excited to see their heroes up close. 

"Look around there are so many young girls here right now who are so excited to go in and see their heroes," said a spectator.

 Becky Pierce, who traveled from Bloomsburg, Pa., with her family, shared, "We got Harper involved in soccer at a really young age and she loves it. 

This is her first US Women's soccer game and I hope she continues to love the sport as much as I did growing up." 

The match featured a special ceremony honoring Alex Morgan, a two-time World Cup winner and recent retiree. 

Her influence on the sport was evident, with many fans naming her as their favorite player. 

Jason Rose from Mt. Laurel, N.J., expressed his excitement, saying, "Super cool. I have 2 daughters so having the ability to show them women's soccer here in Philly is really cool." 

There is growing momentum for Philadelphia to secure a National Women's Soccer League expansion team. 

Jen Leary from Watch Party PHL hosted a pre-game tailgate and emphasized the importance of support, saying, "Especially with FIFA coming I think now is the time to really show there is support for a team here and there is excitement." 

Families like the Fillipelli's found the experience inspiring. 

Lucy Fillipelli, a young soccer player, said, "It's fun and inspirational because I have been watching these people play for a while and it's kind of unrealistic to actually see them in person." 

Her mother, Dawn Fillipelli, added, "This is our time Philly is a great place to see soccer. We have all these stadiums and just a great experience to be able to see US Women's soccer here tonight." 

Portugal won the match 2-1.  

It was Portugal's first every victory against the USWNT.

What's next:

The US Men's National Team is also scheduled to play a friendly match against Paraguay at Subaru Park on November 15th.

Connections: Sports Edition

Today's News

Women's Soccer

USWNT honored Alex Morgan's career at the stadium where she scored her first goal. Brad Smith/ISI Photos/USSF

Alex Morgan stood on the pitch inside Subaru Park in Chester, Pa., one last time Thursday.

Even though she retired last year, this moment ‚Äî standing before the U.S. women's national team as it celebrated her iconic legacy ‚Äî was long overdue.

The stadium roared as the announcer rattled off the 36-year-old's many accomplishments over her 15-year career. Before the current U.S. squad took on Portugal in the first of two friendlies this international window, the younger generation of players watching as they warmed up, thousands of fans began chanting her name.

Advertisement

But no list could measure what Morgan meant to women's soccer.

It was only fitting that a career like Morgan's came full circle in this way, on the field where she scored her first goal for the U.S. 15 years ago.

While still a senior at the University of California, a 21-year-old Morgan entered the pitch for the USWNT as a second-half sub Oct. 6, 2010. The U.S. trailed China, with an at-home unbeaten streak on the line, inside what was then PPL Park in Chester.

Just shy of 13 minutes on the pitch, Morgan overlapped with teammate Abby Wambach, who flicked a header to the young striker. Morgan calmly waited for the right moment, watching the ball closely as it bounced once before her. She then struck it into the back of China's net, recording her goal of 123 goals scored for the United States over a legendary 15-year career.



There are few players as iconic as Alex Morgan. The two-time World Cup winner and Olympic gold medalist is one of the most prolific goal scorers in U.S. women's soccer history, and one of the most recognizable faces in the women's game. Beyond the pitch, she was a staunch advocate for gender equity and equality, having lent her voice for the betterment of the game throughout her career.

Her accolades are plenty: 224 caps for the U.S., a treble winner with Lyon in France and more than a decade in the National Women's Soccer League. Morgan was also instrumental in the fight for equal pay, better working conditions and player protections across country and club, including advocating for players during NWSL's systemic abuse scandal.

As U.S. women's coach Emma Hayes told reporters this week, Morgan ‚Äútranscended' women's football.

‚ÄúThere was nothing she didn't achieve,‚Äù Hayes said. ‚ÄúShe was a player that epitomized everything this program is about. She's an unbelievable credit to her family, because her drive, her desire, her determination to prove herself at the highest level is second to none. You can't go anywhere in this country without them talking about Alex Morgan.‚Äù

Morgan's is among a string of recent retirements from the U.S. women's national team, including those by Ali Krieger, Megan Rapinoe, Becky Sauerbrunn and Alyssa Naeher, who will be honored in her home state of Connecticut on Sunday. As many from her generation, though, Morgan has not strayed far from the game.

Advertisement

She has evolved into a strategic businesswoman, with a slew of ventures started in recent years. In 2021, she co-founded Togethxr, a women's sports media company. The brand rose to fame with its ‚ÄúEveryone Watches Women's Sports‚Äù tagline, seen on shirts around the globe and the front of London City Lionesses jerseys in the Women's Super League.

Earlier this year, Morgan became a minority investor in the San Diego Wave, the last club she played for.

Morgan retired over a year ago on Sept. 5, 2024, after announcing she and her husband, Servando Carrasco, were expecting their second child, Enzo. Three days after her announcement, she ended her career with a symbolic 13 minutes for the San Diego Wave, the same number as her iconic jersey.

‚ÄúI left everything on the field. I did everything I ever wanted to do and more,‚Äù Morgan said after that game. ‚ÄúI feel so at peace because I am ready to start a family. I'm ready to hang up the boots and allow the next generation to flourish and just relish in the spotlight. I'm just ready.‚Äù

This week, Morgan finally received the standing ovation for the legacy she leaves behind with the U.S. On the eve of her celebration, current U.S. players reflected on her impact.

For Arsenal defender Emily Fox, three words come to mind: ‚ÄúConsistent‚Äù and ‚Äúon top.‚Äù

‚ÄúI feel like the entirety of her career, she's always been improving, always wanted to get better. Both on and off the field, she embraces that,‚Äù Fox said. ‚ÄúJust with what she and the team have done for equal pay, also her foundation that she started, joining the San Diego Wave franchise and bringing that to life. With Alex, she's very 360 in the sense that she is on the field and off the field in what she does.‚Äù

Chelsea winger Alyssa Thompson, one of the rising stars in this new U.S. generation, has looked up to Morgan since she started playing soccer. The two were teammates at the 2023 Women's World Cup, when 18-year-old Thompson was the youngest player on that summer's U.S. roster. That's something Morgan could relate to, as the youngest player called up for the U.S. at the 2011 World Cup.

‚ÄúShe has meant so much to me and the game,‚Äù Thompson said. ‚ÄúShe's changed the game for the better. I wouldn't be in the position I am right now if it weren't for the players that came before me, especially Alex, fighting for equality and equal pay.‚Äù

Advertisement

Though the U.S. suffered an early exit from that tournament, Morgan's leadership stayed with her.

‚ÄúWhen we weren't doing as well as we wanted to, and she gave our team a speech, I feel like it really empowered me,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt inspired me to stay together as a team and believe in our team.‚Äù

For midfielder Rose Lavelle, Morgan's goal in the 2019 World Cup semifinal match against England stands out. Lavelle was the first player to hug Morgan after her viral tea celebration, which graced the world's front pages the next day. The goal happened on Morgan's 30th birthday, and the U.S. went on to win their second consecutive World Cup title, with a game-winning goal from Lavelle.

‚ÄúIt's always such a great opportunity to be able to honor and celebrate players like that,‚Äù Lavelle said. ‚ÄúThey are the reason that we are the team we are. They taught us how to be excellent.‚Äù

But it's not just the players who got to play with Morgan who feel her impact on the national team's program. Twenty-one-year-old Ally Sentnor received her first cap with the national team in November, six months after Morgan played her last U.S. game.

‚ÄúLegend, goal scorer, icon are a few words to describe her,‚Äù Sentnor said. ‚ÄúShe was this amazing, heroic, untouchable player that we watched growing up. She was one of my favorite players growing up. I had her jersey, iconic pink prewrap, we all wore it when we were younger, trying to be her.

‚ÄúJust to be on the team now, to be able to honor her, is such a full circle, incredible moment. I can't wait to give her a huge round of applause. She's just done so much for this sport, never mind this team. We owe a lot to her.‚Äù

There were 13 years, 4 months and 17 days between Morgan's first U.S. goal and her last. Her final goal was during the Concacaf W Gold Cup, when she scored against Argentina on Feb. 23, 2024. This fittingly took place in Carson, Calif., about 40 miles from her hometown of Diamond Bar.

Advertisement

But when Morgan reflects on that first goal, she makes a point to give flowers to another player.

‚ÄúIt was an important goal,‚Äù Morgan recently told ESPN. ‚ÄòWith an assist from my hero and idol, Abby (Wambach).‚Äù

In that moment, Wambach set Morgan up for greatness, a ceremonious passing of the torch from one generation to the next.  In many ways, Morgan's entire career was spent preparing to pass that torch for future generations, too.

Before joining The Athletic, she was an enterprise sports reporter for The Record newspaper and NorthJersey.com, where she was for nearly a decade. She's a graduate of Columbia Journalism School in New York City. Follow Melanie on Twitter @melanieanzidei

Title: Eva Gaetino Called Up from U-23 WNT Training Camp to Join USWNT Roster
Description:
Get unrivaled matchday access

ATLANTA (Oct. 24, 2025) ‚Äì Defender Eva Gaetino, who was participating in U.S. Under-23 Women's National Team Training Camp this week outside of Philadelphia, has been called up to the U.S. Women's National Team roster and will join the U.S. camp ahead of the final two matches of the FIFA window.

The USA will face Portugal on Sunday, Oct. 26 at Pratt & Whitney Stadium at Rentschler Field in East Hartford, Conn. (4 p.m. ET on TNT, truTV and HBO Max in English, Universo and Peacock in Spanish and on the radio on Westwood One Sports) and then will take on New Zealand in Kansas City, Mo., on Wednesday, Oct. 29, in the team's first-ever match at CPKC Stadium (8 p.m. ET / 7 p.m. CT, on TNT, truTV and HBO Max in English on Universo and Peacock in Spanish and on the radio on Westwood One Sports and FDP Spanish radio). The match in Connecticut will be presented by Volkswagen. 

U.S. head coach Emma Hayes had originally named 26 players for this camp, but with forward Trinity Rodman having to withdraw due to injury, a roster spot opened up and it has now been filled by Gaetino. The 22-year-old Michigan native was with the USA for the 2024 SheBelieves Cup, but did not see action, and then earned her first and thus far only cap in a 90-minute performance against Argentina on Oct. 30, 2024.

‚ÄúThis is the epitome of the value of the U-23 program,‚Äù said USWNT head coach Emma Hayes. ‚ÄúWe have the U-23s training at the same site as the National Team, so we are easily able to call a player up and it's important for the U-23s to know how much we value them. Eva is a player who has been in with the full team and in with the U-23s, but also out of both teams. No players' journey is the same and certainly no one's career takes a linear path. We gave Eva some pointed feedback over the past year, and she went back to her club, worked every day to get another chance at a call-up, and put into action things we wanted to see in her. She's the most WNT-ready player in this U-23 camp so she'll be a good addition to our training camp roster for the last week.‚Äù

The 5-foot-11 central defender out of Michigan is in her third season, but second full season, with Paris Saint-Germain in France's Premi√®re Ligue after a banner college career at Notre Dame.

October Matches vs. Portugal & New Zealand

GOALKEEPERS (3): Claudia Dickey (Seattle Reign FC; 2) Mandy McGlynn (Utah Royals; 4), Phallon Tullis-Joyce (Manchester United, ENG; 3)

DEFENDERS (9): Jordyn Bugg (Seattle Reign FC; 2/0), Emily Fox (Arsenal FC, ENG; 67/1), Eva Gaetino (Paris Saint-Germain; 1/0), Lilly Reale (Gotham FC; 2/0), Tara McKeown (Washington Spirit; 8/0), Avery Patterson (Houston Dash; 6/1), Emily Sams (Orlando Pride; 5/0), Emily Sonnett (Gotham FC; 110/2), Kennedy Wesley (San Diego Wave; 0/0)

MIDFIELDERS (8): Sam Coffey (Portland Thorns FC; 38/4), Lindsey Heaps (OL Lyonnes, FRA; 167/38), Claire Hutton (Kansas City Current; 6/1), Lo'eau LaBonta (Kansas City Current; 2/0); Rose Lavelle (Gotham FC; 113/25), Olivia Moultrie (Portland Thorns FC; 9/2), Jaedyn Shaw (Gotham FC; 26/8), Lily Yohannes (OL Lyonnes, FRA; 8/1)

FORWARDS (6): Michelle Cooper (Kansas City Current; 8/1), Catarina Macario (Chelsea FC, ENG; 24/11), Yazmeen Ryan (Houston Dash; 12/2), Emma Sears (Racing Louisville; 8/1), Ally Sentnor (Kansas City Current; 12/4), Alyssa Thompson (Chelsea FC, ENG; 22/3)

Connections: Sports Edition

Today's News

Women's Soccer

Catarina Macario of the United States splits defenders during the first half of an international friendly at Subaru Park. Mitchell Leff / USSF via Getty Images

The U.S. women's national team lost 2-1 to Portugal at Subaru Park in Chester, Pa., on Thursday, opening the October international window with a flat performance as they begin preparations for the 2027 World Cup in Brazil.

Midfielder Rose Lavelle put the U.S. ahead just 33 seconds into the game, an electric start that quickly fizzled. What followed was a disjointed showing, a stark difference from the attacking display that fueled a 3‚Äì0 win over Canada at the Allstate Continental Cl√°sico in August.

Advertisement

Portugal capitalized on a defensive lapse in the 41st minute, with Diana Gomez scoring an equalizer off a corner, punishing the U.S. backline. Portugal's second goal came in the 73rd minute from Fatima Pinto on a similar set piece.

It was the first meeting between the two sides since their goalless group-stage encounter at the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup in Auckland, New Zealand. Thursday night's performance served as a reminder that, for all the talk of progress, head coach Emma Hayes still has plenty of work to do to build her roster for next year's World Cup qualifiers.

‚ÄúWe scored a goal and we stopped playing,‚Äù Hayes told the TNT broadcast after the match. ‚ÄúWe didn't look like a team the whole evening both sides of the ball.‚Äù

For the first time in as long as anybody on-site could remember, the USWNT conceded not once but twice from corner kicks.

The first was a product of poor marking. Midfielder Sam Coffey let Portugal's Diana Gomes drift away from her. Forward Catarina Macario seemed to misjudge the flight of the ball. Defender Avery Patterson was backing away from it, leaving Gomes free to head home an equalizer in the 41st minute.

Portugal level it off the corner üéØ pic.twitter.com/kevj4gm60x

‚Äî B/R Football (@brfootball) October 23, 2025



The second Portugal score seemed to be more unfortunate than lackluster. Lavelle challenged F√°tima Pinto for the initial ball. A couple of U.S. defenders were then slow to the second ball, allowing Pinto to beat goalkeeper Phallon Tullis-Joyce with a clean shot from the penalty spot.

After the match, Lavelle took responsibility for the goal.

‚ÄúI have to put my hand up on the second one,‚Äù Lavelle said. ‚ÄúThat was my mark, so I have to be better and just like boot it out and get a better clearance.‚Äù

Portugal score off another corner to take a 2-1 lead over USA üò≤ pic.twitter.com/H2onl5AYoE

‚Äî B/R Football (@brfootball) October 24, 2025



Perhaps the Americans missed their defensive mainstay, Naomi Girma. But Emily Sonnett, Tara McKeown and others have defended hundreds, if not thousands, of corners in their national team and NWSL careers. They, and Hayes, will be disappointed with how they defended set pieces tonight.

Advertisement

‚ÄîHenry Bushnell

Despite the defeat, the night opened with U.S. midfielder Lavelle scoring 33 seconds into the match. She settled the ball and, with a quick turn, shot it through two defenders. The tally stood despite Lavelle appearing to play from an offside position. The friendly did not have VAR.

Pick out that corner, Rose üåπ

USWNT x @VW pic.twitter.com/Fl6225SS44

‚Äî U.S. Women's National Soccer Team (@USWNT) October 23, 2025



Lavelle has been in top form with Gotham FC in the National Women's Soccer League (NWSL) in recent weeks. The midfielder has scored four goals and recorded one assist over the club's last seven games. Four days ago, we saw some ‚ÄúRose Lavelle magic‚Äù when the 30-year-old scored off a free kick, helping Gotham clinch their place in the upcoming NWSL playoffs.

Lavelle is one of the remaining veterans who played against Portugal in the ill-fated 2023 World Cup group stage, helping guide the U.S. through this ongoing season of change, especially as the team works towards World Cup qualifying and head coach Hayes narrows her roster for 2027. Lavelle has the second-most caps on this roster, second only to captain Lindsey Heaps and with only three more caps than defender Sonnett.

It is fitting that Lavelle scored one of the fastest goals in U.S. women's soccer history on the same night as U.S. Soccer honored Alex Morgan. She is, after all, believed to hold the record for fastest goal ever scored, with her 12-second goal against Costa Rica in 2016.

‚ÄîMelanie Anzidei

Before Thursday, the USWNT had not conceded a goal since April 8. Even without several stars, including the most recent scratch of Trinity Rodman, it rolled through friendlies against China, Jamaica, Ireland and Canada ‚Äî four very respectable opponents. The team looked both solid and dynamic.

Advertisement

Thursday was a very different story. After Lavelle's goal, Portugal controlled much of the first half, with more shots and 59 percent possession through 45 minutes. Hayes, standing at the edge of her coach's box on the sideline, repeatedly shouted ‚Äúrhythm!‚Äù ‚Äî presumably because the U.S. had very little of it.

‚ÄúI think we gotta find a way to get control of the ball,‚Äù an apparently frustrated Lavelle told the TNT broadcast at halftime.

U.S. defenders also looked shaky. Portugal's Catarina Amado snuck behind fullback Avery Patterson on the first set piece. Center back McKeown whiffed on a clearance in the box, and goalkeeper Tullis-Joyce had to bail her out with an impressive save. On the ensuing corner, though, Portugal scored ‚Äî the first goal conceded by the USWNT in 491 minutes of soccer.

‚ÄîHenry Bushnell

The USWNT's October roster is full of youth. But at her pre-match news conference Wednesday, Hayes spoke glowingly about her three most experienced players, Lavelle, Heaps and Sonnett.

‚ÄúIt makes me smile thinking about them,‚Äù Hayes said. And then she made a serious point: ‚ÄúYou can't compete to win without experience.‚Äù

Accordingly, she kicked off this three-match international window with about as much experience as possible in the lineup. Lavelle, Heaps and Sonnett all started, along with Olympic gold medalists Emily Fox and Sam Coffey. Several exciting youngsters, such as Lily Yohannes, Claire Hutton and Ally Sentnor, had to settle for places on the bench.

In the very first minute, Lavelle validated that choice with her goal (albeit as offside as it looked), and Sonnett made a few key interventions. But Sonnett also got outjumped on the first Portuguese goal. Throughout the first half, the U.S. looked stale. Portugal was able to break 3-v-3 on multiple occasions, through or around the U.S. midfield. Heaps seemed to struggle defensively.

Advertisement

Midway through the second half, Hayes turned to Yohannes, Hutton and forwards Emma Sears and Yazmeen Ryan (in place of Heaps, Coffey, Macario and Michelle Cooper). But not much about the flow of the game changed.

Some of those subs, and others, should get a chance to start against Portugal on Sunday or against New Zealand next week.

‚ÄîHenry Bushnell

Sunday, Oct. 26 vs. Portugal, in East Hartford, Conn. (Pratt & Whitney Stadium), 4 pm ET

Wednesday, Oct. 29 vs. New Zealand, in Kansas City, Mo. (CPKC Stadium), 8 pm ET

Title: Kasey Keller Says USMNT Must Rekindle Fighting Spirit Ahead of World Cup
Description: Kasey Keller making a save at the 2006 World Cup (Photo by Christof Koepsel/Bongarts/Getty Images) Kasey Keller is a true U.S. Men's National Team legend. A four-time World Cup veteran, he was the starting goalkeeper in two of the four tournaments he played ‚Äî in 1998 and 2006 ‚Äî and delivered countless memorable performances across his 102 appearances for the United States. Among his international highlights are four Concacaf Gold Cup titles and a semi-final run at the 1995 Copa Am√©rica in Uruguay, where the USMNT famously upset Argentina 3‚Äì0. Keller, who shared goalkeeping duties with Brad Friedel during that era, later delivered one of the greatest individual performances in U.S. Soccer history at the 1998 Gold Cup ‚Äî a 1‚Äì0 win over Brazil, the only such victory in the program's history. He made ten saves that day, prompting Brazilian striker Rom√°rio to call it ‚Äúthe greatest goalkeeping performance‚Äù he had ever seen. Keller ranks second all-time among USMNT goalkeepers with 53 wins and recorded 47 clean sheets. His club career was equally distinguished, featuring successful spells in England, Germany, and Spain before finishing his playing days in MLS with the Seattle Sounders. Today, Keller serves as an ESPN pundit, appearing on ESPN FC and F√∫tbol Am√©ricas on ESPN+. In a sit-down interview with RG, Keller reflects on his transition from player to pundit and tackles some of the tougher questions surrounding U.S. Soccer ‚Äî from the challenges faced by the so-called ‚ÄúGolden Generation,‚Äù to defining what success should look like at the 2026 World Cup, to why former stars of his caliber remain largely absent from the national team's leadership structure. ‚Äì You've successfully transitioned from playing to punditry and even become a part-owner of a USL team. How important was it for you to find something meaningful to do after retiring, and how did that path into media and ownership come about ‚Äî was it something that happened naturally, or did it take some time to figure out? ‚Äì You know, it's tricky. A lot of players today earn great salaries, and those numbers keep growing generation after generation. But the reality is most players retire in their mid-30s. I was lucky ‚Äî I almost played until my 42nd birthday, just a few weeks shy ‚Äî but most are done much earlier. And when you think about it, how much money would you have to make in a short career to maintain the same lifestyle for the rest of your life if you retire at 34 or 35? So even from a financial standpoint, most players realize they'll need to do something after they retire. But it's not just about money ‚Äî it's also about self-worth. When you've spent your entire life waking up with a purpose ‚Äî training, preparing for a match, studying opponents ‚Äî suddenly having nothing to prepare for can leave a big void. People say, ‚ÄúOh, it must be great to retire and do whatever you want,‚Äù but after a while, that lack of focus can be tough. I was fortunate that I got to retire on my own terms. I could've played another year, but I chose to stop when I did. Most players don't get that choice ‚Äî either the offers stop coming, or the body gives out. When I stepped away, I thought about what came next. If you want to stay in the game, there are really three main paths: coaching, front office, or media. For me, media made the most sense because of my family. When we moved back to the U.S., my kids started sixth grade ‚Äî their fifth school in their fourth country. I didn't want to uproot them again. Working in broadcasting allowed me to stay put, keep them in school, and still stay involved in the game. I started with the Seattle Sounders' local broadcasts, which also included an ambassador role with the club. Then I signed a full-time contract with ESPN. What I loved about broadcasting after 20 years as a player was having some control over my schedule. Of course, if there was a match on the weekend, I couldn't just skip it, but during the week, I had flexibility ‚Äî something I never had as a player. I remember when the Sounders' broadcasts were run by the Seahawks' media team. One Friday before a home game, I was invited to play in a charity golf event. Normally, Fridays were packed ‚Äî we'd watch training, meet with players and coaches, and have a production meeting. I called my producer, Brian, and asked if I could miss the meeting. In my entire career, I'd only missed training for things like my kids' births or a medical emergency. And his response was, ‚ÄúYeah, of course, just call me later and we'll go over what was said.‚Äù I was shocked ‚Äî that kind of flexibility doesn't exist when you're playing. ‚Äì Looking at U.S. Soccer now from a bit of distance, how do you see the program's overall progress since your playing days? Would you say it has continued to move forward, or has it stagnated ‚Äî maybe even taken a step back in some areas? ‚Äì I think it's a bit of both. There have been periods, especially after the U.S. qualified for the 1990 World Cup, where we probably overachieved in some of our results. And I think that early success created a false sense of expectation ‚Äî that our progress would be steady and linear. People started thinking, ‚ÄúOkay, we've made it this far, so the next step must be the semifinals or the finals.‚Äù But that's not how international football works. There's a reason only a handful of countries ‚Äî France, Germany, Brazil, Argentina ‚Äî consistently win World Cups. It's not random. Some of that overachievement made people believe we'd reached that same level, when in reality, we were still developing the structure and depth needed to sustain it. I remember being part of a panel at the MIT Sloan Analytics Conference, and one of the questions was, ‚ÄúWhy hasn't the U.S., with 350 million people, produced a Messi or a Ronaldo?‚Äù It reminded me of a story. Not long before that, my wife and I were on vacation in Costa Rica. As soon as we landed, people recognized me ‚Äî staff at the airport, workers at the hotel ‚Äî everyone wanted to talk about soccer: the U.S. team, Costa Rica, the World Cup. The sport is a national obsession there. But during that same trip, not a single American tourist stopped me to talk about football. And that, to me, sums it up. In most countries, football is the dream ‚Äî every kid grows up wanting to play for their national team. In the U.S., there are a hundred different dreams. You can grow up wanting to be a football player, or a baseball player, or a snowboarder, or even a skateboarder like Tony Hawk. There's nothing wrong with that diversity, but it means our focus as a sporting culture is spread across so many directions. In places like Argentina or Brazil, it's simple ‚Äî if you're not going to be a footballer, then you figure out what else to do. Here, it's the opposite. ‚Äì When Mauricio Pochettino came in, he talked a lot about building a new culture within the national team. But it raises the question ‚Äî what culture are we talking about changing? Because your generation had already built something strong. You guys competed well in Copa Am√©ricas, won Gold Cups, and were consistently successful. So do you think this idea of ‚Äúchanging the culture‚Äù overlooks some of what was already working before, or is it based on what he saw with this current squad? ‚Äì Yeah, I mean, we got out of World Cup group stages, we competed well. I remember when I was at Leicester, one of my assistant coaches ‚Äî a former Scottish international ‚Äî used to give me a hard time whenever I missed a few club games for World Cup qualifiers. He'd say, ‚ÄúWhy are you worried about that? You'll beat those teams easily.‚Äù And I told him, ‚ÄúReally? How many World Cup group stages has Scotland ever made it out of?‚Äù That was my point ‚Äî what the U.S. achieved during that era wasn't automatic. We often overachieved compared to where we were as a footballing nation. That's part of managing ‚Äî creating an environment where that hunger and competitiveness stay alive. What I really liked in these last few matches was that we finally started talking about football again ‚Äî tactics, movement, missed chances ‚Äî instead of questioning effort and mentality. That's real progress. I actually talked about this once with Thierry Henry. He told me, ‚ÄúWhen you played against Americans ‚Äî club or country ‚Äî you knew you had to match their effort. Maybe they weren't the best team technically, but if you didn't bring the same fight, you'd be embarrassed.‚Äù And he said recently he's noticed a bit of that slipping away. And he's right ‚Äî we're not at a stage yet where pure talent alone can win games against top teams. Back when I was playing for Leicester against Manchester United or Arsenal, we couldn't just go out and play our football and hope for the best. We had to find ways to disrupt them, to fight, to get a result against superior sides. And that's what the U.S. always had ‚Äî that determination to compete, to grind, and to find a way. ‚Äì We're now seeing more U.S. players competing at top clubs and doing well, which is great. But when we talk about culture, I sometimes wonder about the difference between American players and, say, Uruguayans. In Uruguay, each new generation grows up trying to meet the standard set by those before them ‚Äî like God√≠n following players such as Paolo Montero. There's a lineage to live up to. In the U.S., though, many of these players are the standard; they're the first to reach that level. Do you think that lack of an established tradition or benchmark could be part of the challenge when it comes to building a lasting football culture? ‚Äì That's an interesting point, because while some of our players are now at big clubs, those clubs aren't what they used to be. The level of competition and expectations have dropped, and that changes the context. To be fair, many of these players have had very good individual seasons. But I've been there ‚Äî I've had strong personal performances on teams that still finished mid-table. That's what's happening now: talented players doing well individually, but not necessarily leading top teams to success. And that's part of the issue. They've reached those big stages, but not necessarily during the club's strongest period, so they aren't yet establishing themselves as true stars competing for major titles. In earlier years, American players often didn't even get the chance to join top teams, simply because they were American. Now that they do, it's progress ‚Äî but we're still waiting for someone to take that next step and really become a defining figure at the highest level. What's interesting is that while people call this a ‚Äúgolden generation,‚Äù there are also areas where we've gone backwards. There was a time when several American goalkeepers were starting regularly in the Premier League at the same time. That's not the case anymore. And yet, we keep hearing that we're producing more great players ‚Äî but the results don't quite show that in some positions. And finally, just because a player performs well abroad doesn't automatically mean it translates to the national team. I always say, if someone has multiple nationalities, the key question isn't about talent ‚Äî it's about identity. What are you? What do you feel you are? Because when it's 90 degrees, in tough conditions, playing in a difficult away qualifier, I need players who are 100% committed. If you're only choosing the U.S. because it's your best chance to play in a World Cup, that's not enough. ‚Äì What is the real expectation of this USMNT team based on the body of work over the last six years? Two knockout round games at the World Cup? ‚Äì I always look at the World Cup draw and ask myself: should the U.S. get out of that group? Sometimes, yes ‚Äî sometimes, no. Take Qatar, for example. England were favorites to win the group, and when you look at the rest ‚Äî Iran and Wales ‚Äî you'd say the U.S. should finish second. That's a fair expectation. Now go back to Brazil. That group had Germany, Portugal, and Ghana ‚Äî all very strong teams. In that case, it's hard to argue the U.S. should have advanced. They could, sure, but not that they should. That's where expectations get tricky. When people say it's a failure if the U.S. doesn't reach the quarterfinals, I ask: is the U.S. really one of the eight best teams in the world? No, not yet. To get that far, they'd have to beat teams that are better than them. It can happen ‚Äî but it shouldn't be expected. Realistically, the U.S. is still somewhere between 20th and 30th in the world. ‚Äì Then, given how the federation has danced around and many pundits have said that it's only about what happens at the World Cup, maybe doing well at the World Cup would only validate the immediate result and may make winning Gold Cups, Nations Leagues, or Copa Americas even less of a priority? ‚Äì Yeah, I think it's about perspective. Three years out from a big tournament, no one really cares about every single player ‚Äî like a sprinter or a swimmer ‚Äî until they have a real chance to achieve something big, like winning a gold medal. Then people pay attention. The same goes for soccer. Missing one World Cup or qualifying campaign isn't the end of the world. Even historically strong countries face struggles, and it's about understanding the bigger picture. At the same time, the small wins matter. Winning Gold Cups, for example, is important because it builds a winning culture. The only way to create a culture of winning is by actually winning. And I've seen that firsthand ‚Äî we've won with our best team and with mixed squads, and in both cases, players stepped up and grew from the experience. I also believe in putting a team on the field that can win every game. You can't rotate players just for the sake of giving everyone a chance in friendlies ‚Äî those matches often don't reflect the true strength of the team. World Cup qualifying is different because it forces you to play the players who matter. The challenge in recent years has been too many meaningless matches, constant rotation, and coaching changes. Every time a new coach comes in, they expand the net to see everyone, which makes the process feel disjointed and false. It's hard to build momentum or culture in that environment. ‚Äì Why haven't players like you or an Eddie Pope or other past USMNT stars transferred into coaching youth national teams, like say former players do with Argentina or Uruguay? Why has US Soccer closed the door on players who once defended the crest of the US? ‚Äì I'll tell you a good story. J√ºrgen Klinsmann wanted to bring in some new talent and called me to ask if I could step in as the goalkeeping coach for a Gold Cup. At the time, I was broadcasting, and my contract had a clause that if I missed matches, my pay could be affected. I told him, ‚ÄúJ√ºrgen, I can't commit without checking with the club.‚Äù The Sounders and Seahawks thought it was a great idea ‚Äî having their local broadcast analyst on the national team was excellent exposure. So I called J√ºrgen back and said, ‚ÄúThe club's fine with it, but here's what I'll be giving up to make it work. I'm not looking to make more money ‚Äî I've been on four World Cup teams ‚Äî but I shouldn't lose money to coach in the Gold Cup.‚Äù J√ºrgen said, ‚ÄúThat's a fair point. I'll bring it up with U.S. Soccer.‚Äù A short time later, he came back and said, ‚ÄúU.S. Soccer won't cover it.‚Äù I told him, ‚ÄúI'm sorry, but I'm sticking to this. I'm not going to lose money to work for U.S. Soccer.‚Äù I called him and told him, ‚ÄúI will never do that again.‚Äù If U.S. Soccer doesn't value me enough to make up the difference after what I've given to the program, people hesitate to get involved. Former USMNT goalkeeper Kasey Keller sat down with RG and spoke about his memorable experience playing for Milwall, one of the most passionate clubs around. RG spoke to Jerome Opoku about recovering from an ACL injury, playing in the S√ºper Lig, and helping Ghana qualify for the World Cup. RG spoke to Renato Paiva about engineering Benfica's academy, being sacked by Botafogo after beating PSG, and plenty more in an exclusive interview. From coaching U.S. Soccer's youth teams to helping Nashville SC lift their first-ever trophy, Michael Nsien is making his mark on the technical side of the game. Title: ‚ÄòSoccer is the universal language': U.S. men's deaf national team ready for big stage at Rentschler
Description:
Daily e-Edition

Evening e-Edition

Sign up for email newsletters



Sign up for email newsletters

Daily e-Edition

Evening e-Edition

FARMINGTON ‚Äî The practice is lively, fast-paced. The two dozen players are moving in concert, non-stop, as soccer players do.

It is, however, quiet. No whistles, no shouting. In a sport where communication it critical, the U.S. men's deaf soccer team finds its own ways to stay connected.

‚ÄúIt's a mixture of eye contact, recognition of the game, IQ and ASL, sign language,‚Äù says forward Michael Schmidt, 36, one of the oldest and most accomplished players on the U.S. team. ‚ÄúIn a way, deaf players are smarter, because we have to use our eyes more. Coaches are telling us to use your eyes all time, and this is the perfect way; you can't use your voice, you have to use your eyes more. That's how we build that connection, and that's one of the things I was attracted to about this team.‚Äù

U.S. women's soccer team will have star Trinity Rodman back for its match at Rentschler Field



The U.S. team has been in Connecticut all week, training for its match against Germany at Rentschler Field on Sunday at 1 p.m., to be shown on truTV, with streaming available on HBO Max, before the U.S. women's team takes on Portugal at 4 p.m. It's part of preparation for the next big tournament, the Deaflympics in Tokyo in November. The U.S. team won bronze at the Pan American Games last year in Brazil, clinching with a 4-0 win over Mexico to qualify. Schmidt scored twice in that game.

‚ÄúIt's very different from what I expected,‚Äù says Tate Lancaster, who has been with the team since 2020. ‚ÄúI grew up with only one other classmate in school who had hearing aids as well, but we didn't really converse well with each other. But coming onto this team, I really learned how to communicate with sign language, and get back into this whole other community that I didn't really know much about.‚Äù

The 23 players come from all over the country, the age range from 18 to 37. Many have played high school or college soccer despite their hearing impairment, but there they were allowed to wear their hearing aids. In international competitions, players are told to ‚Äútake your ears out‚Äù before the games begin. To be eligible, players have hearing loss of at least 55 decibels, the borderline between moderate and moderately severe, in their better ear. Some players have no hearing and some are completely nonverbal.

‚ÄúYou can't communicate quickly enough by signing while passing the ball,‚Äù Schmidt says, ‚Äúso it's visual, you have to be prepared, two or three plays ahead. Deaf players, we are a little more aware of our surroundings, our emotions, how we communicate with our body language. Every camp, we make sure we have about 20 important signals, get in line, come closer, check two, turn, common language that soccer players know, but it's visual.‚Äù

Interpreters use sign language, or tablets with written instructions to convey the messaging of coaches and trainers as players huddle up.

‚ÄúThe vibe is great energy and a community feel,‚Äù coach Everett Palache says. ‚ÄúThey love each other. That was the biggest thing I stepped into, like ‚Äòholy crap, these guys really like hanging out with each other.' They're like brothers. I try not to mess that up.‚Äù

The U.S. program dates back to 1965, playing in the Deaflympics in Washington, D.C. that year, finishing as high as fourth (in 2008) at the World Deaf Football Championships, taking first at the 2019 Deaf Pan Am games. Since 2022, the program has been a fully-funded part of the U.S. Soccer Federation, along with other extended teams including the women's deaf team, Cerebral Palsy (CP) team, power team, which uses wheelchairs, beach soccer and futsol, or five-on-five soccer. There are specially-designed spaces for the extended teams at U.S. Soccer's Atlanta headquarters. Volkswagen is the deaf team's presenting sponsor.

The chance to travel around the country allows the teams to attract and recruit players. As the U.S. men's deaf team trained at the Farmington Sports Arena, youth teams and coaches, working on adjacent fields, stopped to watch the late afternoon practice ‚Äî its second of the day ‚Äî on Wednesday. The team visited students at the American School for the Deaf in West Hartford on Thursday morning.

‚ÄúSoccer is the universal language,‚Äù Schmidt says. ‚Äú‚Ä¶To play in a professional stadium with fans, on TV, it's going to be a huge honor for us. It's a significant moment to reach out to all players out there and say ‚Äòhey, you can achieve your dreams.' Everybody faces a different kind of adversity, but you can overcome it, you can get to this level, and know that there are resources out there for you. Just because there's a disability doesn't mean you can't play soccer.‚Äù

Dom Amore: Dan Hurley, Rick Pitino bring old-school fire to a new era of the Big East



Originally from Cleveland, Schmidt joined the team in 2014 after a local college coach forwarded him an e-mail about tryouts. He drove to Pittsburgh to check it out, ‚Äúand the rest has been history,‚Äù he says.

In 2016, he played at the World Cup in Italy. In a fifth-place game against England, Schmidt scored the winning goal as the fourth kicker in an OT shootout.

‚ÄúI just remember doing the celebration my family and friends told me to do,‚Äù Schmidt says. ‚ÄúYou get to experience a moment not many people get to experience.‚Äù

Lancaster, from Overland Park, Kansas, graduated from Baker University, but found himself idle and bored during the pandemic when he saw a notice for a tryout in Louisville on social media. He traveled on his own expense, made the team and is now back into soccer, coaching at the youth level back home in Kansas City, as well as playing.

‚ÄúThe biggest challenge I have playing with my teammates here is communicating with them,‚Äù Lancaster says. ‚ÄúEspecially if I'm on the back line, I have to figure out a way to talk to them when they're facing the other way and understand how to react to what their movement is. We come up with key words, condense a lot of our phrases, quick signs, we kind of come up with our own language within the team. Basic sign language, but they have more meaning in the situation we're in. Once we cross the white line, we're all playing the same sport.‚Äù

The chance to play on television Sunday will give two young players he has been coaching in Kansas City the chance to watch Lancaster on a big stage.

‚ÄúI hope kids see that they can do the same thing,‚Äù Lancaster says. ‚ÄúA couple of kids back home, they're hard of hearing and kind of going through a hard time, playing with other kids who are hearing and they're struggling to fit in. This game gives them that outlet, so I hope when they see us on TV, see me playing back home, they have the realization that I can do whatever I set their mind to.‚Äù

Dom Amore: Azzi Fudd ‚Äòowning her space' to begin her last dance with UConn women



Playing for the U.S. team has changed his life in multiple ways. Lancaster, 31, was on the team when it became part of the U.S. soccer community. He met his fianc√©, Gracie Fitzgerald, who plays on the U.S women's deaf team. ‚ÄúI have this team to thank for it,‚Äù he says.

The team prides itself on its speed and quickness. ‚ÄúWe play with pride, play with passion,‚Äù Schmidt says, ‚Äúthe game of soccer is supposed to be fun. Make them remember you on the field. This is why we're here.‚Äù

Palache, who was brought 20 years of coaching experience to the job in 2024, realized during a trip to Washington and a game against Alexandria (Va.) Soccer Association that he was in the right place.

‚ÄúThat really showed us our grit and our desire and I knew that they had another level to them,‚Äù Palache says. ‚ÄúI had wondered how far we could push them, and that  game itself pushed them. I'm ultra-competitive, and that's when I knew they were equally competitive and I was in the right spot. The profile that we're looking for is resiliency, athleticism, adaptability. We've actually come up with an acronym off of ‚ÄòDEAF,' they've got to have drive, got to give effort, got to be adaptable, got to have faith in the process. ‚Ä¶ We do something called a legacy letter, get them to think about what is their purpose, and everyone said they want to leave a legacy they can live up to, and inspire the next generation that it's possible.‚Äù

Title: Kasey Keller Says USMNT Must Rekindle Fighting Spirit Ahead of World Cup
Description: Kasey Keller making a save at the 2006 World Cup (Photo by Christof Koepsel/Bongarts/Getty Images) Kasey Keller is a true U.S. Men's National Team legend. A four-time World Cup veteran, he was the starting goalkeeper in two of the four tournaments he played ‚Äî in 1998 and 2006 ‚Äî and delivered countless memorable performances across his 102 appearances for the United States. Among his international highlights are four Concacaf Gold Cup titles and a semi-final run at the 1995 Copa Am√©rica in Uruguay, where the USMNT famously upset Argentina 3‚Äì0. Keller, who shared goalkeeping duties with Brad Friedel during that era, later delivered one of the greatest individual performances in U.S. Soccer history at the 1998 Gold Cup ‚Äî a 1‚Äì0 win over Brazil, the only such victory in the program's history. He made ten saves that day, prompting Brazilian striker Rom√°rio to call it ‚Äúthe greatest goalkeeping performance‚Äù he had ever seen. Keller ranks second all-time among USMNT goalkeepers with 53 wins and recorded 47 clean sheets. His club career was equally distinguished, featuring successful spells in England, Germany, and Spain before finishing his playing days in MLS with the Seattle Sounders. Today, Keller serves as an ESPN pundit, appearing on ESPN FC and F√∫tbol Am√©ricas on ESPN+. In a sit-down interview with RG, Keller reflects on his transition from player to pundit and tackles some of the tougher questions surrounding U.S. Soccer ‚Äî from the challenges faced by the so-called ‚ÄúGolden Generation,‚Äù to defining what success should look like at the 2026 World Cup, to why former stars of his caliber remain largely absent from the national team's leadership structure. ‚Äì You've successfully transitioned from playing to punditry and even become a part-owner of a USL team. How important was it for you to find something meaningful to do after retiring, and how did that path into media and ownership come about ‚Äî was it something that happened naturally, or did it take some time to figure out? ‚Äì You know, it's tricky. A lot of players today earn great salaries, and those numbers keep growing generation after generation. But the reality is most players retire in their mid-30s. I was lucky ‚Äî I almost played until my 42nd birthday, just a few weeks shy ‚Äî but most are done much earlier. And when you think about it, how much money would you have to make in a short career to maintain the same lifestyle for the rest of your life if you retire at 34 or 35? So even from a financial standpoint, most players realize they'll need to do something after they retire. But it's not just about money ‚Äî it's also about self-worth. When you've spent your entire life waking up with a purpose ‚Äî training, preparing for a match, studying opponents ‚Äî suddenly having nothing to prepare for can leave a big void. People say, ‚ÄúOh, it must be great to retire and do whatever you want,‚Äù but after a while, that lack of focus can be tough. I was fortunate that I got to retire on my own terms. I could've played another year, but I chose to stop when I did. Most players don't get that choice ‚Äî either the offers stop coming, or the body gives out. When I stepped away, I thought about what came next. If you want to stay in the game, there are really three main paths: coaching, front office, or media. For me, media made the most sense because of my family. When we moved back to the U.S., my kids started sixth grade ‚Äî their fifth school in their fourth country. I didn't want to uproot them again. Working in broadcasting allowed me to stay put, keep them in school, and still stay involved in the game. I started with the Seattle Sounders' local broadcasts, which also included an ambassador role with the club. Then I signed a full-time contract with ESPN. What I loved about broadcasting after 20 years as a player was having some control over my schedule. Of course, if there was a match on the weekend, I couldn't just skip it, but during the week, I had flexibility ‚Äî something I never had as a player. I remember when the Sounders' broadcasts were run by the Seahawks' media team. One Friday before a home game, I was invited to play in a charity golf event. Normally, Fridays were packed ‚Äî we'd watch training, meet with players and coaches, and have a production meeting. I called my producer, Brian, and asked if I could miss the meeting. In my entire career, I'd only missed training for things like my kids' births or a medical emergency. And his response was, ‚ÄúYeah, of course, just call me later and we'll go over what was said.‚Äù I was shocked ‚Äî that kind of flexibility doesn't exist when you're playing. ‚Äì Looking at U.S. Soccer now from a bit of distance, how do you see the program's overall progress since your playing days? Would you say it has continued to move forward, or has it stagnated ‚Äî maybe even taken a step back in some areas? ‚Äì I think it's a bit of both. There have been periods, especially after the U.S. qualified for the 1990 World Cup, where we probably overachieved in some of our results. And I think that early success created a false sense of expectation ‚Äî that our progress would be steady and linear. People started thinking, ‚ÄúOkay, we've made it this far, so the next step must be the semifinals or the finals.‚Äù But that's not how international football works. There's a reason only a handful of countries ‚Äî France, Germany, Brazil, Argentina ‚Äî consistently win World Cups. It's not random. Some of that overachievement made people believe we'd reached that same level, when in reality, we were still developing the structure and depth needed to sustain it. I remember being part of a panel at the MIT Sloan Analytics Conference, and one of the questions was, ‚ÄúWhy hasn't the U.S., with 350 million people, produced a Messi or a Ronaldo?‚Äù It reminded me of a story. Not long before that, my wife and I were on vacation in Costa Rica. As soon as we landed, people recognized me ‚Äî staff at the airport, workers at the hotel ‚Äî everyone wanted to talk about soccer: the U.S. team, Costa Rica, the World Cup. The sport is a national obsession there. But during that same trip, not a single American tourist stopped me to talk about football. And that, to me, sums it up. In most countries, football is the dream ‚Äî every kid grows up wanting to play for their national team. In the U.S., there are a hundred different dreams. You can grow up wanting to be a football player, or a baseball player, or a snowboarder, or even a skateboarder like Tony Hawk. There's nothing wrong with that diversity, but it means our focus as a sporting culture is spread across so many directions. In places like Argentina or Brazil, it's simple ‚Äî if you're not going to be a footballer, then you figure out what else to do. Here, it's the opposite. ‚Äì When Mauricio Pochettino came in, he talked a lot about building a new culture within the national team. But it raises the question ‚Äî what culture are we talking about changing? Because your generation had already built something strong. You guys competed well in Copa Am√©ricas, won Gold Cups, and were consistently successful. So do you think this idea of ‚Äúchanging the culture‚Äù overlooks some of what was already working before, or is it based on what he saw with this current squad? ‚Äì Yeah, I mean, we got out of World Cup group stages, we competed well. I remember when I was at Leicester, one of my assistant coaches ‚Äî a former Scottish international ‚Äî used to give me a hard time whenever I missed a few club games for World Cup qualifiers. He'd say, ‚ÄúWhy are you worried about that? You'll beat those teams easily.‚Äù And I told him, ‚ÄúReally? How many World Cup group stages has Scotland ever made it out of?‚Äù That was my point ‚Äî what the U.S. achieved during that era wasn't automatic. We often overachieved compared to where we were as a footballing nation. That's part of managing ‚Äî creating an environment where that hunger and competitiveness stay alive. What I really liked in these last few matches was that we finally started talking about football again ‚Äî tactics, movement, missed chances ‚Äî instead of questioning effort and mentality. That's real progress. I actually talked about this once with Thierry Henry. He told me, ‚ÄúWhen you played against Americans ‚Äî club or country ‚Äî you knew you had to match their effort. Maybe they weren't the best team technically, but if you didn't bring the same fight, you'd be embarrassed.‚Äù And he said recently he's noticed a bit of that slipping away. And he's right ‚Äî we're not at a stage yet where pure talent alone can win games against top teams. Back when I was playing for Leicester against Manchester United or Arsenal, we couldn't just go out and play our football and hope for the best. We had to find ways to disrupt them, to fight, to get a result against superior sides. And that's what the U.S. always had ‚Äî that determination to compete, to grind, and to find a way. ‚Äì We're now seeing more U.S. players competing at top clubs and doing well, which is great. But when we talk about culture, I sometimes wonder about the difference between American players and, say, Uruguayans. In Uruguay, each new generation grows up trying to meet the standard set by those before them ‚Äî like God√≠n following players such as Paolo Montero. There's a lineage to live up to. In the U.S., though, many of these players are the standard; they're the first to reach that level. Do you think that lack of an established tradition or benchmark could be part of the challenge when it comes to building a lasting football culture? ‚Äì That's an interesting point, because while some of our players are now at big clubs, those clubs aren't what they used to be. The level of competition and expectations have dropped, and that changes the context. To be fair, many of these players have had very good individual seasons. But I've been there ‚Äî I've had strong personal performances on teams that still finished mid-table. That's what's happening now: talented players doing well individually, but not necessarily leading top teams to success. And that's part of the issue. They've reached those big stages, but not necessarily during the club's strongest period, so they aren't yet establishing themselves as true stars competing for major titles. In earlier years, American players often didn't even get the chance to join top teams, simply because they were American. Now that they do, it's progress ‚Äî but we're still waiting for someone to take that next step and really become a defining figure at the highest level. What's interesting is that while people call this a ‚Äúgolden generation,‚Äù there are also areas where we've gone backwards. There was a time when several American goalkeepers were starting regularly in the Premier League at the same time. That's not the case anymore. And yet, we keep hearing that we're producing more great players ‚Äî but the results don't quite show that in some positions. And finally, just because a player performs well abroad doesn't automatically mean it translates to the national team. I always say, if someone has multiple nationalities, the key question isn't about talent ‚Äî it's about identity. What are you? What do you feel you are? Because when it's 90 degrees, in tough conditions, playing in a difficult away qualifier, I need players who are 100% committed. If you're only choosing the U.S. because it's your best chance to play in a World Cup, that's not enough. ‚Äì What is the real expectation of this USMNT team based on the body of work over the last six years? Two knockout round games at the World Cup? ‚Äì I always look at the World Cup draw and ask myself: should the U.S. get out of that group? Sometimes, yes ‚Äî sometimes, no. Take Qatar, for example. England were favorites to win the group, and when you look at the rest ‚Äî Iran and Wales ‚Äî you'd say the U.S. should finish second. That's a fair expectation. Now go back to Brazil. That group had Germany, Portugal, and Ghana ‚Äî all very strong teams. In that case, it's hard to argue the U.S. should have advanced. They could, sure, but not that they should. That's where expectations get tricky. When people say it's a failure if the U.S. doesn't reach the quarterfinals, I ask: is the U.S. really one of the eight best teams in the world? No, not yet. To get that far, they'd have to beat teams that are better than them. It can happen ‚Äî but it shouldn't be expected. Realistically, the U.S. is still somewhere between 20th and 30th in the world. ‚Äì Then, given how the federation has danced around and many pundits have said that it's only about what happens at the World Cup, maybe doing well at the World Cup would only validate the immediate result and may make winning Gold Cups, Nations Leagues, or Copa Americas even less of a priority? ‚Äì Yeah, I think it's about perspective. Three years out from a big tournament, no one really cares about every single player ‚Äî like a sprinter or a swimmer ‚Äî until they have a real chance to achieve something big, like winning a gold medal. Then people pay attention. The same goes for soccer. Missing one World Cup or qualifying campaign isn't the end of the world. Even historically strong countries face struggles, and it's about understanding the bigger picture. At the same time, the small wins matter. Winning Gold Cups, for example, is important because it builds a winning culture. The only way to create a culture of winning is by actually winning. And I've seen that firsthand ‚Äî we've won with our best team and with mixed squads, and in both cases, players stepped up and grew from the experience. I also believe in putting a team on the field that can win every game. You can't rotate players just for the sake of giving everyone a chance in friendlies ‚Äî those matches often don't reflect the true strength of the team. World Cup qualifying is different because it forces you to play the players who matter. The challenge in recent years has been too many meaningless matches, constant rotation, and coaching changes. Every time a new coach comes in, they expand the net to see everyone, which makes the process feel disjointed and false. It's hard to build momentum or culture in that environment. ‚Äì Why haven't players like you or an Eddie Pope or other past USMNT stars transferred into coaching youth national teams, like say former players do with Argentina or Uruguay? Why has US Soccer closed the door on players who once defended the crest of the US? ‚Äì I'll tell you a good story. J√ºrgen Klinsmann wanted to bring in some new talent and called me to ask if I could step in as the goalkeeping coach for a Gold Cup. At the time, I was broadcasting, and my contract had a clause that if I missed matches, my pay could be affected. I told him, ‚ÄúJ√ºrgen, I can't commit without checking with the club.‚Äù The Sounders and Seahawks thought it was a great idea ‚Äî having their local broadcast analyst on the national team was excellent exposure. So I called J√ºrgen back and said, ‚ÄúThe club's fine with it, but here's what I'll be giving up to make it work. I'm not looking to make more money ‚Äî I've been on four World Cup teams ‚Äî but I shouldn't lose money to coach in the Gold Cup.‚Äù J√ºrgen said, ‚ÄúThat's a fair point. I'll bring it up with U.S. Soccer.‚Äù A short time later, he came back and said, ‚ÄúU.S. Soccer won't cover it.‚Äù I told him, ‚ÄúI'm sorry, but I'm sticking to this. I'm not going to lose money to work for U.S. Soccer.‚Äù I called him and told him, ‚ÄúI will never do that again.‚Äù If U.S. Soccer doesn't value me enough to make up the difference after what I've given to the program, people hesitate to get involved. Former USMNT goalkeeper Kasey Keller sat down with RG and spoke about his memorable experience playing for Milwall, one of the most passionate clubs around. RG spoke to Jerome Opoku about recovering from an ACL injury, playing in the S√ºper Lig, and helping Ghana qualify for the World Cup. RG spoke to Renato Paiva about engineering Benfica's academy, being sacked by Botafogo after beating PSG, and plenty more in an exclusive interview. From coaching U.S. Soccer's youth teams to helping Nashville SC lift their first-ever trophy, Michael Nsien is making his mark on the technical side of the game.
