Title: Austin Butler In Early Talks To Play Sonny Crockett In ‚ÄòMiami Vice' Movie At Universal
Description:
By Justin Kroll 

Film Editor


	After Deadline broke the news that Michael B. Jordan was in line for the Ricardo Tubbs role in Universal‚Äòs Miami Vice movie being directed by Joseph Kosinksi, the studio now looks to have zeroed in on his partner. Deadline is hearing Austin Butler is in early talks to star as iconic TV detective James ‚ÄúSonny‚Äù Crockett, the character made famous by Don Johnson in Michael Mann's 1980s TV series.


	Sources say it is still early days and no deals are done, but after scheduling was worked out for the  film to shoot later in 2026, Butler is engaging and interested. As for Jordan, his deal to play Tubbs is also early days.

	











	Eric Warren Singer and Dan Gilroy are penning the script. Dylan Clark and Kosinski are producing.




			Watch on Deadline		







	Universal had no comment.


	The film is dated for August 6, 2027, and this incarnation will explore the glamour and corruption of mid-1980s Miami, inspired by the pilot episode and first season of the NBC series that would influence the pop culture from fashion to filmmaking.


Miami Vice is based on characters created by Anthony Yerkovich from the series executive produced by Yerkovich and Mann. Singer was the first scribe that originally developed the adaptation with Kosinski. The show rocketed Johnson to pin-up-star status in the role of white-suit-wearing Sonny Crockett, while Philip Michael Thomas played his partner Tubbs.


	If a deal is able to close, add the part to another high-profile role for Butler following his Oscar-nominated work in Elvis, followed by films like Dune: Part Two and most recently Caught Stealing. 












	We will let you know more as this unfolds.

Title: Emman Atienza Dies: Filipino Social Media Star Found Dead In L.A. Was 19
Description:
By Melanie Goodfellow 

Senior International Film Correspondent


UPDATED with cause of death: Filipino social media star Emmanuelle ‚ÄòEmman' Atienza, who courted controversy with her lifestyle videos in her native Philippines, has died at her home in L.A. The Los Angeles County Medical Examiner confirmed her cause of death as suicide by ligature hanging. She was 19.


	Her death has sparked a raft of condolence messages from fans alongside Filipino celebrities and influencers, such as Bea Borres, Gretchen Fullido and Heart Evangelista, as well as debate over whether she had been a victim of cyberbullying and what role this had played in her death. 

	











	Atienza, who was the daughter of the Filipino TV personality Kim Atienza and Felicia Atienza, a celebrity entrepreneur and fitness guru, had moved to L.A. over the summer.


	Her parents confirmed the news of their daughter's death in a post on Instagram. She is reported to have died on October 22. 


	‚ÄúIt's with deep sadness that we share the unexpected passing of our daughter and sister, Emman,‚Äù read the post. ‚ÄúShe brought so much joy, laughter, and love into our lives and into the lives of everyone who knew her. Emman had a way of making people feel seen and heard, and she wasn't afraid to share her own journey with mental health. Her authenticity helped so many feel less alone.‚Äù


	‚ÄúTo honor Emman's memory, we hope you carry forward the qualities she lived by: compassion, courage, and a little extra kindness in your everyday life.‚ÄùThe post, which was also signed by Atienza's siblings Jose and Eliana, did not reveal the cause of her death.


DEADLINE RELATED VIDEOS:


	Atienza, who had 875,000 follows on TikTok and another 225,000 on Instagram, had a built a profile around her posts vaunting her wealthy lifestyle but also for tackling mental health issues and pushing back against conservative values in the Philippines.


	She found herself in the middle of a media storm in November 2024, after she posted a video of dinner with friends, including Filipino singer Rhaila Tomakin and Miss World Philippines Krishnah Gravidez, in a high-end Japanese restaurant in Manila as they played ‚Äúguess the bill.‚Äù


	The TikTok trend involves friends guessing the bill when they eat out at a restaurant, with the person whose estimate is the closest settling the account.  

	











	The bill at the Japanese restaurant was eventually revealed to be 133,000 Philippine Peso ($2,268). The post sparked a backlash in the Philippines, where the average monthly wage is less than a fifth of that sum. 


	Atienza took the post down and withdrew from social media for a time but hit back in subsequent posts at suggestions that her family's wealth derived from its political connections on her father's side.


	Her recent posts from L.A. had mainly consisted of videos showing her settling into life in the city as well as performing acrobatic feats at outdoor gym spaces and climbing wall centers.

Title: ‚ÄòBoston Blue' Goes Global: Donnie Wahlberg's ‚ÄòBlue Bloods' Spinoff Sells To Over 100 Markets
Description:
By Stewart Clarke 




EXCLUSIVE: Detectives Danny Reagan and Lena Silver will be playing the blues around the world after a raft of international buyers bought Boston Blue. The show has its world premiere in Cannes at the MIPCOM market last week. Following the international launch it has sold into over 100 markets, Deadline can reveal.


Donnie Wahlberg reprises his role as Reagan in the Blue Bloods offshoot. His character relocates from NYC to Boston in the series, and Sonequa Martin-Green is his new partner, Lena Silver. The show launched on CBS in the U.S. on October 17 and episodes stream on Paramount+ the day after playing on linear.

	











	The roster of international buyers snapping up the show includes AXN Asia and Coupang Play in Korea. M-Net has acquired it for Africa and Sky for New Zealand. In Europe, Boston Blue has landed at pay-TV giant Sky in German-speaking territories. It is also headed to Play Media in Belgium, Cosmote TV in Greece, S√≠minn in Iceland and beIN in Cyprus and Turkey. Elsewhere, it will be on CTV and in Australia on Paramount+.




			Watch on Deadline		







	Internationally, the procedural format has enduring appeal so hopes were high for Boston Blue, especially as its forebear, Blue Bloods, had established a strong fanbase globally. Quickly getting to 100 territories, however, is at the top end of expectations. The show is sold by Paramount Global Content Distribution, which cut the international deals.


	Wahlberg is an exec producer on the series. In Cannes he talked up the possibility of a Blue Bloods‚ÄìBoston Blue franchise. CBS certainly has form here, with NCIS and other procedurals spawning numerous spinoffs. International sales are key to getting these shows funded and making them profitable and that responsibility falls to Lisa Kramer's PGCD division.


	As well as Wahlberg and Martin-Green, the Boston Blue cast includes Maggie Lawson, Marcus Scribner, Mika Amons, Gloria Reuben and Ernie Hudson. The series is produced by CBS Studios in association with Jerry Bruckheimer Television. Brandon Sonnier and Brandon Margolis are showrunners and exec producers. Bruckheimer, KristieAnne Reed and Wahlberg are also EPs.

	











	Meanwhile, we hear more international deals are in the works for Boston Blue.

Title: Jennifer Coolidge & Nicole Scherzinger To Star In Rebel Wilson's ‚ÄòGirl Group'
Description:
By Zac Ntim 

International Reporter


Jennifer Coolidge and Nicole Scherzinger have signed on to star in Rebel Wilson's Girl Group. 


	Wilson is writing, directing, producing, and starring in the project for Live Nation Studios and Future Artists Entertainment.


	The project will see Wilson play a pop diva who's been kicked out of her own girl group's reunion tour and slapped with a sentence of court-ordered community service, but seizes the chance to stage a comeback by coaching a group of misfit teen girls for a major record label audition.


	The ensemble cast also includes Randall Park (WandaVision), Sheridan Smith (Mrs Biggs), Jamie Lee O'Donnell (Derry Girls), comedian Guz Khan (Man Like Mobeen) and Jolene (Star Trek: Enterprise) as well as Pussycat Doll Ashley Roberts, Spice Girl Melanie Chisholm and All Saints' Shaznay Lewis who will form girlband Girlfriends alongside Wilson's character. Loren Gray will also star.

	










			Watch on Deadline		







	The film will also be produced by Wilson under her Camp Sugar banner, alongside Matt Williams of Future Artists Entertainment, and executive produced by Live Nation Studios. Chris Scott (Wicked) is the choreographer.

Title: ‚ÄòThe Graham Norton Show' Producer To Make BBC Claudia Winkleman Chat Show After Presenter Quit ‚ÄòStrictly Come Dancing'
Description:
By Jake Kanter 

International Investigations Editor


EXCLUSIVE: Claudia Winkleman is poised to land her own BBC chat show ‚Äî and Deadline can reveal it will be made by the company behind The Graham Norton Show.


The Daily Mail first reported on the talk show plans on Friday, but Deadline can now confirm that the series is set to be produced by So Television. 


	A deal for the chat show has not yet been finalized, though talks are said to be at an advanced stage. The news comes hours after Winkleman and Tess Daly dropped a glitterball bombshell about their plans to quit Strictly Come Dancing this year.




			Watch on Deadline		







	
	
		
					Related Stories		
	













	News
	



	
		
					'Strictly Come Dancing' Presenters Tess Daly & Claudia Winkleman Exiting BBC Series		
			















	Casting
	



	
		
					Laura Linney & Rhys Ifans To Lead BBC Parkinson's Drama 'But When We Dance'		
			








	Sources told Deadline that Winkleman and Daly's social media announcement about their Strictly exit ‚Äúblindsided‚Äù the BBC, which did not release a statement on the matter until two hours later. One person said it spoke to the ‚Äúpresenter power‚Äù the duo wield. 

	











	Winkleman, who also hosts The Traitors, earned her chat show stripes by stepping in for Norton earlier this year when the Irish presenter was on a break from his BBC duties. ‚ÄúTo be honest, nobody is more livid than me,‚Äù Winkleman joked when opening the show.  


	The idea is that Winkleman's series will broadcast when The Graham Norton Show is off-air, meaning there will be no clashes between the shows and they will not be competing for guests. The BBC recently renewed The Graham Norton Show for another three years, while its recent run of episodes has boasted eye-catching bookings, including Taylor Swift. 


	So Television was founded by Norton and business partner Graham Stuart. The company, which also made Netflix comedy special Hannah Gadsby's Gender Agenda, is owned by ITV Studios.


	The BBC declined to comment.

Title: Jon M. Chu swears that Crazy Rich Asians sequel TV show is actually getting made
Description:
It's only gotten weirder, over the last few years, that Jon M. Chu has never been able to get any traction on a sequel to his 2018 blockbuster hit Crazy Rich Asians. After all, Chu's no longer just ‚ÄúCrazy Rich Asians director Jon M. Chu‚Äù: He's become something of a full-blown cottage industry, propelled most of all by the success of last year's Wicked, and the expected performance of its sequel next month. This guy is the stud from which Warner Bros. is hanging pretty much all of its holiday hopes, which only makes the multiple fizzled attempts to build on his first big hit feel all the more incongruous.

But, no more: Chu swears that the previously announced Crazy Rich Asians sequel show is the real deal, with scripts written, and production ready to go‚Äîjust as soon as he gets a green light. (God only knows when that'll be, since he's also still on the hook to do a lot of other stuff, including directing a Hot Wheels move for J.J. Abrams for some unfathomable reason.) Chu was making these promises during a recent conversation with Esquire, where he swears up and down that there will actually be more Crazy Rich Asians at some point. ‚ÄúIt's a real thing. We have scripts, and we're waiting to be officially ready to go. Our cast will be there.‚Äù (Chu does not then specify ‚Äúour cast,‚Äù which feels like it could be a major sticking point for translating the film's universe into TV.)

Meanwhile, Chu also talked a bit about the difficulties in adapting Kevin Kwan's follow-up novel to Crazy Rich Asians, China Rich Girlfriend, for the screen: ‚ÄúIt's hard to do the continuation of the books,‚Äù he told Esquire. ‚ÄúBecause our characters changed so much in the first movie. It's so different [from] the books, actually, even though it feels like it's the same. So you couldn't go one-to-one. But we can use a lot of inspiration from the book to dig out more story from it.‚Äù

News of the TV continuation began circulating back in February, i.e., right after Chu handed Warner Bros. his latest fresh basket of money.

Title: Diablo Cody is currently working on "fun and crazy" Jennifer's Body sequel
Description:
Jennifer Check goes both ways, but right now, she's going forward into a sequel. Original writer Diablo Cody is ‚Äúworking on it right now,‚Äù director Karyn Kusama said in a recent interview with Deadline. ‚ÄúI'm very excited to hear what comes of it,‚Äù she added. ‚ÄúI know some of the bones of it, so I'm not going to give anything away, but it sounds fun and crazy like the first film. And I have no doubt that Diablo will do something absolutely incredible with it.‚Äù

Jennifer's Body, which bowed in 2009, was a victim of its sex-heavy mis-marketing and a lot of misogynistic backlash against both Diablo Cody and its star Megan Fox, but it's become a veritable cult classic in the years since. ‚ÄúI'm just so grateful that the film managed to find its audience, perhaps on a different timeline than any of us might have expected or hoped for, but I'm just so thankful that the work continues to speak to people,‚Äù Kusama said. ‚ÄúI'm just so satisfied by that.‚Äù It's continued to speak to both Fox and co-star Amanda Seyfried as well, as both have mentioned their interest in a sequel in various interviews throughout the years. ‚ÄúI think we're making another one,‚Äù Seyfried said this past March. ‚ÄúI didn't confirm it! I said, ‚ÄòI think.' We're working on it.‚Äù Despite her clear desire not to pull a Tom Holland, the use of ‚Äúwe‚Äù is notable. In 2021, Fox also expressed interest in resurrecting Jennifer. ‚ÄúI don't think it's a hard movie to make a sequel to,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI mean, they should make it into a TV series. That would be cool.‚Äù

Cody herself was ‚Äúnervous to get back into that,‚Äù as she previously told Deadline of her feelings regarding the film she admitted was a ‚Äúcommercial and critical disaster‚Äù at the time. Like Kusama, however, the film's new cult status healed some of that hurt. ‚ÄúAnd then this magical thing happened the last few years where that movie found an audience and people began to really appreciate it,‚Äù Cody continued. ‚ÄúAnd it gave me the confidence to say, ‚ÄòYou know what? I never lost my passion for that world and I want to do another one.' So, I'm here.‚Äù

Title: Frankie Muniz shares photographic evidence of Malcolm In The Middle reunion
Description:
Silencing the Malcolm In The Middle revival skeptics, who refuse to believe that a reunion season of the offbeat turn-of-the-century sitcom is on the way, star Frankie Muniz shared a photo of himself with his television brothers, Justin Berfield and Christopher Kennedy Masterson, from the set of the new limited series. Earlier today, Muniz posted the picture on X, the everything website, where you can take a break from incessant Nazi memes to ask Muniz, ‚ÄúWhere's Dewey?‚Äù In his caption, he revealed that he was told to refrain from sharing photos, but he remained steadfast in his assertion that no one's the boss of him (now). ‚ÄúI was told not to post this yet, but then I listened to this song,‚Äù Muniz wrote. ‚ÄúI'm just too excited for y'all to see the new episodes and I miss my brothers.‚Äù

Frankie Muniz, Justin Berfield, and Christopher Masterson Credit: Frankie Muniz/X

To answer the question on everyone's mind, Erik Per Sullivan, who played Dewey on the show, is too busy getting his master's degree from Harvard to appear on the reunion. He also retired from acting in 2010, when he last appeared on screen in the Joel Schumacher drama Twelve. On the upcoming series, entitled Malcolm In The Middle: Life's Still Unfair, newcomer Caleb Ellsworth-Clark will play Dewey. Berfield, who returns to play Malcolm's brother Reese, had also retired from acting and hadn't worked since he produced and starred on one episode of 2010's Sons Of Tucson.

Malcolm In The Middle: Life's Still Unfair is set for a four-episode revival on Disney+ in 2026.

Title: Kylo Ren fans have already flown a "Save #TheHuntForBenSolo" banner over Disney
Description:
Adam Driver kicked up a bit of a shitstorm in the Star Wars universe this week, revealing that‚Äîin the midst of an extremely fallow period for the franchise in movie theaters‚Äîhe and Steven Soderbergh had taken the time to cook up, for their own pleasure, a cool-sounding movie centered on Driver's old pal Kylo Ren/Ben Solo. Said film apparently excited everybody who heard about it, right up until it was run straight into the thresher known as ‚ÄúDisney CEO Bob Iger.‚Äù Iger apparently shot the idea down purely on its premise‚Äîi.e., that Solo might still be alive after Rise Of Skywalker‚Äîand ‚Äúthat was that.‚Äù

But there's nothing quite like a Star Wars fanbase scorned, and so now fans who've just learned about this project have already started making big, flashy gestures in defense of it. Specifically, Collider reports that somebody apparently rented a plane to fly over Disney headquarters with a banner trailing behind it, calling on the studio to ‚ÄúSave #TheHuntForBenSolo.‚Äù The banner was apparently organized by fan Lianna Al Allaf, who wanted Iger and his fellow executives to know ‚Äúhow much the character of Ben Solo means to so many of us, and that the fans really do want this movie.‚Äù

It feels like Driver must have known what he was doing when he aimed the fandom's ire straight at Iger: In the interview, he makes it clear that pretty much everybody at Lucasfilm was onboard for the project, and that Iger (and fellow executive Alan Bergman) were the specific stumbling points. (They apparently hadn't heard that you can bring characters back in this universe by just having Oscar Isaac mumble ‚ÄúSomehow, so-and-so returned.‚Äù) It's very hard to imagine Iger about-facing on something like this‚Äîhe's made it clear that new Star Wars movies are going to be pretty much the safest bets possible, even as the series' TV side has made ambitious swings like Andor‚Äîbut, hey, we'll take Star Wars fans being mad about a cool-sounding movie getting killed over Star Wars being mad that, like, women exist any day of the week.

Title: First look at Dark Winds ' fourth season blows into town
Description:
Something windy this way comes. Dark Winds is blowing back into town for season four. AMC announced earlier today that the fourth season of Dark Winds will hit AMC and AMC+ on February 14. The new season will pull Lt. Leaphorn (Zahn McClarnon), Chee (Kiowa Gordon), and Manuelito (Jessica Matten) away from the comfort of the Navajo Nation and into the seedy underbelly of 1970s Los Angeles in search of a missing Navajo girl. Season four is also welcoming new cast members into the investigation, including Franka Potente, Isabel DeRoy-Olson, Chaske Spencer, Luke Barnett, and, Bosch himself, Titus Welliver.

Along with the announcement, AMC released a short first look at season four, which should prepare viewers for the ominous milieu of LA noir. As always, though, the show is all about character, with Leaphorn narrating the clip, pining for the days when murders weren't so frequent.



We've long been fans of Dark Winds, which has brought originality and nuance to a tired genre. ‚ÄúEnter AMC's Dark Winds,‚Äù A.V. Club‚Äòs TV writer Saloni Gajjar wrote in her season three premiere recap. ‚ÄúThe neo-Western thriller is pointedly set in the '70s but also feels contemporary in its tackling of themes like bigotry, classism, and violence against Indigenous people. The show distinguishes itself with a propulsive suspense, grounded protagonists, immersive cinematography, and, crucially, a rare spotlight on Native American voices both on- and off-screen.‚Äù

Dark Winds is based on Tony Hillerman's Leaphorn & Chee novels. Hillerman published his final installment of the series in 2006, before his 2008 death. Afterward, his daughter, Anne Hillerman, took up the series and published Spider Woman's Daughter in 2013. Her most recent entry, Lost Birds, came out in 2024.

Dark Winds returns on February 15 at 9 P.M. EST on AMC and AMC+.

Title: Did Simon Cowell & Lauren Silverman Quietly Get Married? Everything We Know So Far
Description:
Lauren Silverman sparks marriage rumors after changing her Instagram name to Lauren Cowell ahead of Simon Cowell's upcoming Netflix documentary, ‚ÄúSimon Cowell: The Next Act.‚Äù Silverman has surprised fans by changing her social media name to Lauren Cowell. 

The 48-year-old mother of two, who has been engaged to beloved ‚ÄúAmerica's Got Talent‚Äù judge Simon Cowell since 2021, deleted her old Instagram account, @LaurenMichelle1974, and launched a new one under @LaurenMichelleCowell.

While the reason behind the sudden change remains unclear, HELLO! reported that the mystery will likely be addressed in Simon Cowell's upcoming Netflix documentary, ‚ÄúSimon Cowell: The Next Act.‚Äù EntertainmentNow could not independently verify the wedding reports.

The new Netflix docuseries ‚ÄúSimon Cowell: The Next Act‚Äù is set to premiere in December 2025 and will follow the entertainment mogul as he assembles a brand-new boy band. The project promises an inside look at Cowell's next chapter, both professionally and personally.

Lauren and Simon, who met in 2004 while vacationing in Barbados, got engaged on Christmas Eve 2021 after nearly two decades together. The couple shares one son, Eric, 11, while Lauren also has a son, Adam, 19, from her previous marriage to real estate entrepreneur Andrew Silverman.

Lauren and Simon's romance began years after their initial meeting. At the time, Lauren was married to Andrew Silverman, who was also a friend of Simon's. Their relationship eventually turned romantic, and in 2013, the pair publicly confirmed they were expecting their first child together.

A post shared by Simon Cowell (@simoncowell)

For Cowell, fatherhood was a turning point. Speaking to Kelly Clarkson, he recalled, ‚ÄúFrom that moment I saw the scan, I was like, ‚ÄòThat is it, I'm besotted.' Now I just cannot imagine my life without him. He's the most amazing thing that ever happened to me.‚Äù

A post shared by HELLO! Magazine (@hellomag)

The couple's engagement took place in Barbados, where they first met. Lauren's engagement ring reportedly features a 20-carat oval diamond, estimated to be worth a small fortune, given Cowell's net worth of $600 million.

As for their upcoming wedding, Cowell teased during ‚ÄúAmerica's Got Talent‚Äù Season 18 that the big day will be an intimate affair. ‚ÄúI am planning it all, otherwise I know what will happen ‚Äì there will be 600 people and it'll get out of control, like my 50th birthday party,‚Äù he joked. ‚ÄúNo one knows when it's going to be ‚Äì that'll be a surprise, even for Lauren.‚Äù

In an earlier interview with People in 2023, Cowell described wedding planning as ‚Äúeasy,‚Äù explaining that after years together, they want to keep things simple and meaningful.

EntertainmentNow has reached out to Simon Cowell's representative for comment and is awaiting a response.

Title: Emma Stone Reveals the Stage Name She Used ‚Äî and Her Real Name!
Description:
Emma Stone is a famous name nowadays; however, that wasn't always a moniker that was used by the star. Indeed, that's not even her real name. She was born Emily Stone, but also used another name at one point.

‚ÄúI actually adopted a stage name for six months,‚Äù Emma revealed during a Wednesday, October 22 appearance on The Late Show with Stephen Colbert. ‚ÄúBecause the Screen Actors Guild, it's like a business bureau, you can only have one person with that name. I was 16, and I decided I wanted to be ‚ÄòRiley,' so I was ‚ÄòRiley Stone.'‚Äù

Although she thought the name was ‚Äúbeautiful,‚Äù it didn't quite work out.

‚ÄúI had a guest part on Malcolm in the Middle,‚Äù she told the host. ‚ÄúAnd they kept going, ‚ÄòRiley,' ‚ÄòRiley,' and I had no idea who they were talking to. Truly. So I was like, ‚ÄòI cannot be Riley.' It came out of nowhere. I was just like, ‚ÄòCool name. I'll just be Riley.'‚Äù

However, when it failed to stick, ‚ÄúI then changed it to ‚ÄòEmma,' because it's close enough to ‚ÄòEmily.'‚Äù

In April 2024, Emma was asked by The Hollywood Reporter, ‚ÄúDoes anyone in the industry call you Emily?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen I get to know them, people that I work with do,‚Äù the star answered. ‚ÄúIt's just because my name was taken [by another actress in SAG]. Then I freaked out a couple of years ago. For some reason, I was like, ‚ÄòI can't do it anymore. Just call me Emily.'‚Äù

THR then asked, ‚ÄúIf some fan came up to you and said, ‚ÄòCan I take a selfie, Emily?' would you be like, ‚ÄòIt's Emma.'‚Äù

Emma admitted, ‚ÄúNo. That would be so nice. I would like to be Emily.‚Äù

Emma is far from the only star to use a stage name. In fact, plenty of famous figures use snappy pseudonyms. You might be asking who ‚Äî well, check out the names (real and faux) below.

Gigi Hadid was born Jelena Noura Hadid, according to Harper's Bazaar.

Lady Gaga is really Stefani Joanne Angelina Germanotta.

Rihanna is Robyn Rihanna Fenty.

Joaquin Phoenix was known as Joaqu√≠n Rafael Bottom.

Natalie Portman was Neta-Lee Hershlag.

Miley Cyrus was given the name Destiny Hope Cyrus when she came into the world.

Cardi B is Belcalis Almanzar.

Lana Del Rey was Elizabeth Woolridge Grant.

Reese Witherspoon was born as Laura Jeanne Reese Witherspoon.

Drake is really Aubrey Drake Graham.

And that's just to name a few!

Title: Derek Hough Leaves Fans in Tears Over His Interaction With a Young Fan in a Wheelchair
Description:
Derek Hough shared a beautiful moment with a young fan in the ‚ÄúDancing with the Stars‚Äù ballroom, and fans have praised him for his kindness. 

A post shared by Derek Hough (@derekhough)

The young fan's name is Cesily Collette Young. In her Instagram bio, she states: ‚ÄúPlay expert, Artist, chef, and a wheely fun girl. Account managed by parents.‚Äù She is also a talented actress who held the role of Young Nessarose in the film ‚ÄúWicked.‚Äù 

Young had a fantastic night interacting with the professional dancers and their celebrity dance partners on Wicked Night in Week 6. Her Instagram account is filled with happy photos from Show Day on Tuesday, October 21. However, the last post on Instagram from the night is a video of her dancing on the ballroom floor with DWTS Season 34 host and professional dancer Derek Hough. It is a moving moment.

Hough captioned his video with a simple message, writing, ‚ÄúMay I have this dance @cesilycollette @dancingwiththestars @wickedmovie.‚Äù Fans reacted to the post, flooding it with comments about how beautiful this interaction was and how lovely Hough and, of course, Young are! 

‚ÄúSo lovely, and of course Derek would be out there dancing with her. He is an exceptionally kind and thoughtful man,‚Äù a fan wrote. 

‚ÄúOh my heart Derek you are going to be the best daddy!‚Äù another comment reads. Many fans shared the same sentiment with another commenter stating, ‚ÄúBless his heart. He seems like a wonderful man. I can already see that he is going to be a great dad.‚Äù 

‚ÄúCrying good tears,‚Äù a fan shared. ‚ÄúI use a wheelchair and use to do musical theatre but i got sick and now for over 15 years i have been unable to perform. This is beautiful.‚Äù

A post shared by Cesily Collette (@cesilycollette)

Earlier in the night, Young had shared a photo on Instagram of herself and Hough. She looked lovely in her black dress while Hough had on a dashing green suit. The pair smiles into the camera. 

The caption reads, ‚ÄúIt's a 10 to be at @dancingwiththestars.‚Äù 

Fans reacted to the post with praise for Young. ‚ÄúSo happy to see you there Cesily you look adorable!‚Äù a comment reads. ‚ÄúSaw you on my screen and immediately went ‚ÄòYESSSS THATS MY GIRL CC!!!!!'‚Äù another shared. 

A third comment reads, ‚ÄúI just saw you in the crowd. You look beautiful tonight, as usual.‚Äù

Title: Third-Place Contestant Debbie Siebers Predicts Mel Owens' Likely Winner on 'The Golden Bachelor'
Description:
‚ÄúThe Golden Bachelor‚Äù season 2, starring Mel Owens, is quickly coming to an end as the former NFL star has narrowed the contestants down to his final two women. After visiting hometowns on the Oct. 22 episode, Owens chose to move forward with Cindy Cullers, 60, and Peg Munson, 62, and had to say a heartfelt goodbye to Debbie Siebers, 65.

With Cindy and Peg being total opposites, Siebers shared her take on who she truly believes will win over Owens' heart in the very end.

Unfortunately, Debbie Siebers was not given a rose by Mel Owens after hometowns' week. Still, in a recent interview with Parade, she shared the woman she strongly believes will capture his heart at the finale.

‚ÄúThey're so different,‚Äù Siebers said of Cindy Cullers and Peg Munson. When describing Munson, Siebers shared that the burst of energy viewers saw on their screens of the former firefighter was the real deal. ‚ÄúShe'd be the first to bolt out of bed [in the Bachelor house] at 5 a.m., and she's already in the jacuzzi and working out, and she's very fun,‚Äù she said.

As for Cullers, she is a lot more reserved, with Siebers stating that she ‚Äúis just so calming to be around. She's got this demeanor. Even when she was cooking in the kitchen, she's just got this calmness and ease about her.‚Äù

A post shared by The Golden Bachelor (@goldenbachabc)

But who does Siebers really think will ultimately get a proposal out of Owens? ‚ÄúPeg really brings the fun out of him and I think because of all the mantras and the toasts that he always did was to love happiness and fun. And I think he's looking for that lightheartedness and fun, nothing too heavy but just somebody who's going to make him come out of himself a little bit more. So I think it might be Peg.‚Äù

Munson quickly became a fan-favorite on ‚ÄúThe Golden Bachelor‚Äù thanks to her full-of-life personality and spontaneity. She left a lasting impression on Owens right from the very start after stepping out of the limo in a bombsuit. Munson used to work as a firefighter and bomb technician in Las Vegas, Nevada.

Munson earned her first one-on-one date with Owens in episode 4, and the two went to the Orange County Fair, where Owens shared that he admired Munson's ‚Äúhigh level of energy.‚Äù It was clear that Munson had a way of getting the playful side out of Owens and made him feel young again. Who doesn't want that?

During hometowns week, Owens got the chance to meet Munson's only daughter, Dakota, from her first and only marriage. Although she hit him with a few tough questions, he admired Dakota's strong bond with her mother and wanted to protect her heart. 

With Munson and Culler being polar opposites, it's hard to predict who Owens will ultimately choose on ‚ÄúThe Golden Bachelor.‚Äù

Title: Derek Hough Reveals Hidden Meaning Behind Emotional DWTS Dance With Wife Hayley
Description:
‚ÄúDancing With the Stars‚Äù judge Derek Hough and his wife, Hayley Erbert, shared details of their heartbreaking family loss recently. The couple's emotional 2024 dance on ‚ÄúDWTS‚Äù had a hidden meaning that's now very clear.

In October 2024, Hough and Erbert performed a dance to Benson Boone's ‚ÄúBeautiful Things.‚Äù The couple recently shared the heartbreaking story of their miscarriage, and now it's clear that there was a hidden meaning in that special performance.

Erbert suffered a miscarriage last year, which the couple revealed in a video posted on their Instagram accounts on October 15.

‚ÄúThere are some things in life that change you forever. For us, this is one of those things,‚Äù Erbert wrote in the caption. ‚ÄúA chapter of love, loss, heartbreak, and everything in between.‚Äù

She continued, ‚ÄúAs we are now in October, Pregnancy and Infant Loss Awareness Month, we share this part of our story to honor our baby that never made it earthside. One in four pregnancies end in miscarriage, a silent heartbreak so many families know, and one we unfortunately had to experience.‚Äù

Erbert added, ‚ÄúAs we share this, know that there's a rainbow not far behind. ‚ô•Ô∏èüåà‚Äù

The video shows the excitement surrounding the pregnancy and ends with the heartbreak of suffering a miscarriage.

On October 20, Hough shared a photo from the performance, noting, ‚ÄúNow that you know our story, this moment holds a much deeper meaning. Beautiful Thing(s) ‚ù§Ô∏è.‚Äù

A post shared by Derek Hough (@derekhough)

Hough and Erbert's fans flooded the comments section with emotional messages.

‚ÄúWow! I felt the emotion then, and feeling it all over again with a new perspective!‚Äù one fan shared.

Another fan wrote, ‚ÄúThis is even more heartbreaking now üò≠, you went through so much and you're still such bright lights, I wish you nothing but happiness forever üíñ.‚Äù

‚ÄúYour marriage has endured so much in such a short time ‚Ä¶ your family will thank you some day for the strength you have brought to your relationship and a bond that others will not understand,‚Äù one of their fans noted.

Another person wrote, ‚ÄúJust wow. So much to go through. And now, when I watch this performance, I will cry even more for your heartache. I truly admire the strength you both have and your openness to share. I am so excited for your rainbow baby to come! ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äù

Comment

 Save my name, email, and website in this browser for the next time I comment.

 





Œî

Title: Scott Cooper on ‚ÄòSpringsteen: Deliver Me from Nowhere' Expectations
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

It's interesting to hear ‚ÄúSpringsteen: Deliver Me from Nowhere‚Äù director Scott Cooper say he's realizing that this may not be the movie people were expecting about Bruce Springsteen. The interesting part: ‚Äúrealizing‚Äù is in the present tense.

Warren Zane's book of the same name (sans the ‚ÄúSpringsteen‚Äù part of the film's title) is about a famous musical artist basically retreating from the world to write and perform what many think is still his greatest album, ‚ÄúNebraska.‚Äù Oh, and Springsteen recorded ‚ÄúNebraska‚Äù on a wonky piece of equipment and, trying to transfer this particular piece of music over to vinyl, so it could be mass produced for sale, turned out to be quite the challenge ‚Äî and a large part of the book focuses on this particular technical task.

 








Related Stories ‚ÄòBugonia' Review: Jesse Plemons Tries to Save the World from Emma Stone in Yorgos Lanthimos' Blunt Big-Pharma Hostage Thriller ‚ÄòSir√¢t' Wins Top Prize at the 2025 Chicago International Film Festival: Full Winners List 

So, on the surface, not really a book that screams ‚Äúthis should be a movie‚Äù! But the fact it's not, and that this story isn't what people are going to be expecting out of a movie about Bruce Springsteen (played by Jeremy Allen White), is what makes it interesting in the first place. This isn't a film about Springsteen performing stadium anthems to masses of fans (though, we do get one scene like that), it's about Springsteen deconstructing his own identity, which led to an album title track about a mass murderer performed by Springsteen in the first person.

 











			Popular on IndieWire		






It's a big week for ‚ÄúNebraska.‚Äù As the film chronicles, Springsteen refused to do any press for the album, which led to record store patrons just, one day, stumbling upon a brand new Bruce Springsteen album that sounded like nothing he had done before. In contrast, Bruce Springsteen has been everywhere the last few weeks promoting not just this film, but the release of a new ‚ÄúNebraska‚Äù box set that includes the Holy Grail for Springsteen fans, ‚ÄúElectric Nebraska.‚Äù 

Again, as we see in the film, Springsteen did attempt to record the ‚ÄúNebraska‚Äù songs with the E Street Band, but something about the moody, echo-y tone of the original recordings was being lost in the studio. So, he and his manager, Jon Landau (played by Jeremy Strong, in what has to be one of his most earnest and sweetest roles to date) set out to convince the record company that what started as a demo tape should be released as the album, with the promise that something much bigger was just over the horizon. (Which would wind up being ‚ÄúBorn in the U.S.A.‚Äù)

Ahead, Cooper takes us through his journey with this film. (And, yes, his own realizations about what an audience might expect from a Springsteen film as opposed to what an audience might like.) A journey he tried to make in the same spirit Springsteen made ‚ÄúNebraska.‚Äù Though, obviously, he didn't get the studio to agree to the whole ‚Äúno press‚Äù part of that spirit. And he makes it pretty clear, he'd have loved to skip this part.

 










The following interview has been edited and condensed for length and clarity.

IndieWire: In a week that the ‚ÄúElectric Nebraska‚Äù outtakes are finally being released, in the spirit of that, what outtakes can we expect from ‚ÄúDeliver Me from Nowhere‚Äù?

Scott Cooper: Well, I generally never put anything from an outtake that wasn't included in the film. Because I feel if it should ever be seen, it should be in the movie.

Bruce does not agree with this philosophy. 

Bruce does not agree with that. But it did take him 43 years for ‚ÄúElectric Nebraska.‚Äù But what you do hear in the film is the E Street Band performing ‚ÄúElectric Nebraska,‚Äù with Jeremy singing the vocals, which is really nice. It's interesting both are coming out on the same day‚Ä¶

What a coincidence. 

But there are quite a few scenes that are quite wonderful of Jeremy singing that I just wanted to capture. One incredible performance from him and the E Street Band [not in the film] is ‚ÄúDancing in the Dark.‚Äù It's really quite lovely, but it feels like maybe for a different film. We are obviously more focused on ‚ÄúNebraska.‚Äù But if one were to have a coda where we are looking forward to what we might expect, that would be it. 

 










Right, Jon Landau famously told Bruce that the ‚ÄúBorn in the U.S.A.‚Äù album needed one more hit and ‚ÄúDancing in the Dark‚Äù was the last thing written at the last minute and becomes his biggest hit. There's your post-credits scene.

And Bruce told Landau, ‚ÄúIf you want that song, you effin' write it.‚Äù So Bruce stormed off and wrote that song in a day.

Speaking of, this movie isn't a tidy story‚Ä¶

Oh, no, not at all.

Even the making of ‚ÄúNebraska.‚Äù It's not just, ye goes to this house in New Jersey and records ‚ÄúNebraska,‚Äù then after that releases ‚ÄúBorn in the U.S.A.‚Äù The two albums are so intertwined and, to someone who doesn't know the story, it might be confusing, but you lean into that. It's remarkable how much you stick to the book.

The biggest challenge with the drama of ‚ÄúNebraska‚Äù is internal. There's really no band. There's no evil producer we see in films. There's no real tension apart from Al Teller, the head of Columbia Records, telling Jon Landau they can't play this. It's one man alone with his thoughts and a four-track recorder and I think it's one of the most emotionally charged creative acts in modern music. But the big question for me is, how do you make solitude cinematic? You're not shooting a film filled with concerts or crowds. You're shooting stillness in a man wrestling with how honest he can be in his work. My guiding principal was to make the film like how Bruce made ‚ÄúNebraska.‚Äù 

 










How so?

Minimalist. Dark. 

‚ÄúNo press tour.‚Äù

No press tour! It's interesting, Bruce says, ‚ÄúI don't even know how to explain this album.‚Äù I don't even know how to explain the film apart from to say it's about a neglected soul repairing himself through music. 

You should have tried to pull off no press. ‚ÄúJust like the album, we are not going to promote this movie.‚Äù

If I didn't have to do press, Mike, I wouldn't. No one would know anything about me or my process, if I'm being frank.

That's fair.

Alas, here I am.

Was there any moment in his life you wanted to include but couldn't? Maybe even just because it didn't match up with this particular timeline.

So many people have preconceived notions about a music film about Bruce Springsteen. Or a film that they want to see like the ‚ÄúBorn in the U.S.A.‚Äù or ‚ÄúBorn to Run‚Äù story. People have ownership over Bruce Springsteen because I know people who have seen him 140 times. So, this is probably the most unexpected story that folks will get about a music icon. Or a man, in my estimation, who is the soul of American music. I'm realizing this film is not what people expected. Now whether it's what they wanted is another thing.

What do you mean by ‚Äúrealizing‚Äù?
 










Well, I played the film in Telluride, New York, Madrid, Rome, Berlin, Le√≥n, and people didn't expect this story about Bruce Springsteen to be told. And for many people didn't know this was a chapter in Bruce's life that was so painful and so personal, for an album that became so enduring for him. I think people think of Bruce Springsteen, the casual fan, as the ‚ÄúBorn in the U.S.A.‚Äù tour, or maybe the ‚ÄúBorn to Run‚Äù tour. If you look at his autobiography, ‚ÄúBorn to Run,‚Äù most every chapter is very lengthy. The chapter on the making of ‚ÄúNebraska‚Äù is maybe one or one and a half pages. And Bruce said it was too painful to relive that. So, now we are reliving it. 

Speaking of his book, this film is so much about his relationship with his father. There's that part in his book when he talks about winning his Oscar for ‚ÄúStreets of Philadelphia,‚Äù setting it on his parents' kitchen table and his dad says, ‚ÄúOK, you win.‚Äù

You know, Bruce and I have discussed other chapters in his life. I suppose it will remain to be seen if folks want to see those films from Scott Cooper and Bruce Springsteen. But there are plenty of chapters left, I think, to tell. But it's hard to get folks off the sofa to see movies these days that don't rain glass and concrete or men in leotards. 

 










Speaking of other chapters, you actually do get into another interesting chapter of his life not many people know about post-‚ÄúNebraska.‚Äù Earlier this year, Bruce released ‚ÄúTracks II,‚Äù which includes the 1983 Los Angeles Garage Sessions. Your movie actually gets into that era, too, and Bruce is not in a good place when he's living in LA.

Oh, incredibly so. It's so interesting we are debuting the film in Los Angeles within a mile of where he wrote ‚ÄúCounty Fair.‚Äù And there was a time I considered ending the film in Los Angeles. But it seemed fitting, at least, for this chapter, for him to go home. Because Bruce is New Jersey's favorite son. But the film ends with a man walking away from the camera, looking forward. The song that closes the film was recorded by Bruce in 2000 at Madison Square Garden, the live version with the E Street Band of ‚ÄúAtlantic City.‚Äù In a moment of great despair Bruce Springsteen says to Jon Landeau, ‚ÄúWhat we're doing with these songs, it's making me nauseous. Listen to what we're doing to ‚ÄòAtlantic City.'‚Äù What I wanted to show was, the film ends in 1982, but ‚ÄúAtlantic City‚Äù will be in the rotation in a very heavy was later on in Bruce's life. Because they did get it right, the E Street Band.

Yeah, all the ‚ÄúNebraska‚Äù songs now, they sound great with the band.
 










‚ÄúOpen All Night.‚Äù 

Didn't he open with that in LA last year?

Well, for good reason, I was at that show. Bruce said, ‚ÄúI've got something for ya.‚Äù 

Oh, he did that for you?

That was for me.

I want to ask about Paul Walter Houser as Mike Batlan. In the film, Mike is portrayed as a confidant as Bruce records the album. But in reality they, at least later, have some strife. How did you approach that? Did Bruce interject at all how he was portrayed?

Yeah, that was the only relationship in the film that I changed the tenor of. I don't know if you've seen any of my other films‚Ä¶

I have.

They are devoid of humor. And I thought it would be nice that Mike Batlan would serve as, not any kind of comic foil, but someone who is very different to Bruce and his life. Someone who is deeply humane and kind and wants the best for Bruce, because it's a different color. That is not the relationship he had with Mike Batlan. And I didn't think it was important to discuss that unless I'm telling a much larger story about Bruce Springsteen. And Bruce loved the portrayal of Mike Batlan by Paul Walter Hauser. The movie aligns very close to fact. The things I have altered a bit was Mike Batlan and Faye, who was a amalgam of a few women Bruce was seeing. 

 










There's a small moment when Jeremy Strong as Jon Landau is on the phone. He says goodbye, then there's a pause and before he hangs up he does a ‚Äúha ha ha‚Äù laugh before he hangs up. The crowd loved that. 

You know, Jeremy Strong is well known for playing cold, calculating characters. Kendall Roy. Roy Cohn. I've known Jeremy a long time. He was cut out of my film ‚ÄúBlack Mass.‚Äù But I wanted to see tender, warm, passionate, and a man who laughed easily because that's who Jon Landau is. And for people who know Jon Landau well, they think Jeremy has captured him perfectly. That's a testament to Jeremy's devotion to getting it right, because he did a great deal of research on a man who is behind the man. And was out of the frame, by design. And people who have known Bruce and Jon's relationship and have spent time with them, far more than I ever have, think Jeremy White and Jeremy Strong have so beautifully captured their relationship. 

You told a story at New York Film Festival about losing your house in the fires and Bruce invited your family to stay at his house.

I did?

Yes.

Well, that did happen. We lived in Bruce's place. And when my daughter's guitar burned, Bruce replaced that. So often you are told not to meet your heroes for fear they will disappoint. And Bruce Springsteen far exceeded my expectations in every regard. 

 










A 20th Century release, ‚ÄúSpringsteen: Deliver Me from Nowhere‚Äù is now in theaters.

Title: The ‚ÄòSmiling Friends' Creators Tell Us Why the Show Won't Run as Long as ‚ÄòSouth Park' or ‚ÄòThe Simpsons'
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Animated TV shows have a way of sticking around when they get big. Most famously, there's ‚ÄúThe Simpsons,‚Äù which has been airing on Fox for 35 years with few signs of stopping. But other popular shows ‚Äî ranging from kids' fare like ‚ÄúSpongebob Squarepants‚Äù to edgier adult programs like ‚ÄúFamily Guy‚Äù and ‚ÄúSouth Park‚Äù ‚Äî have 10 or even 20+ years and counting of new seasons under their belt. 

Adult Swim‚Äòs ‚ÄúSmiling Friends,‚Äù an absurdist and experimental series that has become an online cult favorite, has over the course of its short run increasingly grown in popularity. The series, which follows the unhinged misadventures of charity workers dedicated to making people happy, is currently airing its third season, and in a sign of confidence from its network, was already renewed for two additional seasons in 2024. Is there a world where ‚ÄúSmiling Friends‚Äù runs for 20 years like ‚ÄúSouth Park?‚Äù

 








Related Stories Cinema Eye Honors 2025 Unveils First Round of Honorees and Nominees for Year's Best Documentary Films and Series Jane Schoenbrun to Make TV Debut with ‚ÄòBlack Hole' Comic Adaptation for Netflix 

‚ÄúFuck no,‚Äù ‚ÄúSmiling Friends‚Äù co-creator Michael Cusack says bluntly in an interview with IndieWire, along with his creative partner Zach Hadel. ‚ÄúIt's renewed for four and five now and we'll see how we feel at the end of that. It could be a natural wrap-up then. Zach and I change our minds every day on this. We don't want it to be a show that outstays its welcome and goes on forever. But we're also very lucky to get this show up, so there's a nice little middle ground. Zach and I have made a promise to each other where we'll always be honest and say, ‚ÄòLook, do we want to keep going with this, or do we want to wrap it up on a high note?' So we'll do Seasons 4 and 5, and see how we feel.‚Äù

 










Until then, Cusack and Hadel have their hands full working on the show; the pair write and direct every 11-minute episode, and voice almost the entire main cast along with numerous supporting or recurring characters. It's a lot of work, although Hadel describes their creative process as ‚Äúvibes-based.‚Äù 

‚ÄúIt starts with Michael and I hanging out, most of the time in an online call. It used to be Skype, you know, whatever the app is, rest in piece Skype, but we used to just go with that and just shoot the shit. And a lot of the time it's us looking at what we find funny, what we find interesting, what engages us?‚Äù Hadel says. ‚ÄúWe kind of test each other and build up and build out the best version of whatever idea we're on is, and it's like Dan Aykroyd's Crystal Skull vodka. It refines through the stones, over and over until it's purified.‚Äù

Once they have their script, Cusack estimates it takes about a year for an episode to get fully produced. Over its first two seasons, ‚ÄúSmiling Friends‚Äù became known for its experimental animation, frequently mixing in different techniques like 3D animation, claymation, and puppetry into its 2D world for surreal effect. 

‚ÄúIt's a hard show to make, it's a show that probably actually needs double the crew to make,‚Äù Cusack said. ‚ÄúBut, you know, after all the chaos and the hardships going through it, I always look back and I I think, like, no, actually, it's probably good, that it's hard, because then it creates something special.‚Äù

 










‚ÄúIf we didn't have a team around us there'd be like half an episode of the show out by now,‚Äù Hadel says.

Season 3 of ‚ÄúSmiling Friends‚Äù has begun with several memorable episodes, including a premiere that introduces a pitiable CGI character named ‚ÄúSilly Samuel‚Äù voiced by Connor O'Malley, or the third episode, which parodies obsessive fan culture with a mole man obsessed with main characters Pim and Charlie. The most memorable episode so far, though, is the second, which departs from the typical formula of the series to focus on supporting character Mr. Frog (voiced by Cusack), a wealthy mega-celebrity humanoid frog who has been the focus of an episode every season. 

Cusack and Hadel say the character was an immediate favorite upon first working on the show in 2018 and, while they usually want to leave other characters introduced as clients for the Smiling Friends charity as one-offs, they came up with the idea to do a ‚ÄúMr. Frog episode‚Äù every season. This one, ‚ÄúLe Voyage Incroyable de Monsieur Grenouille,‚Äù sees Mr. Frog (having become president in a Season 2 episode) go through a spiritual crisis that ends with him finding inner piece and turning into a photorealistic frog. Originally, the episode focused on him going from president to dictator of the world, but Hadel says the idea fell through because it wasn't original enough, so they pivoted into a weirder, more serious direction.

 










‚ÄúIt also is a thing where the fact that it's serious is the joke,‚Äù Cusack says. ‚ÄúThe joke is that it's Mr. Frog, it's so stupid, unbelievably stupid that he's going through this. We never want to be sending serious messages with this show.‚Äù

The episode arguably hits peak absurdity when Mr. Frog's father appears in a live-action sequence to dress down his son, played in a cameo by a green paint-covered Creed Bratton, best known for his work in ‚ÄúThe Office.‚Äù As Hadel tells it, neither he nor Cusack had ever seen ‚ÄúThe Office‚Äù or knew much about Bratton before he was cast. However, while looking for someone to play the character, they had trouble casting for the profile of an intimidating man in his 60s. A member of the production staff, however, was friends with Bratton, and convinced Hadel and Cusack to watch an audition tape he sent over for the small role.

‚ÄúThat is my favorite kind of cameo, where we didn't get him for any of the cool reasons. It was just like, ‚ÄòOh, he did the part well,'‚Äù Hadel says. ‚ÄúI think he nailed it, and that's why he got it was because he did a good job.‚Äù

While Cusack and Hadel don't know exactly how long it'll be before they end ‚ÄúSmiling Friends,‚Äù they do know how they want to end it. The two tell IndieWire that a movie spinoff wrapping up the adventures of Pim and Charlie is the perfect way they want the series to conclude.

 










‚ÄúWe'd love to end it with that, whenever we feel like the show has ended, I'd feel like that be a good way,‚Äù Hadel says. ‚ÄúAnd I don't think we would do it in the middle of the show, like other shows have done it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI like the idea of a movie wrapping up, because we've got an 11-minute show, right?‚Äù Cusack adds. ‚ÄúIt's hard to do a finale in that format. Doing a movie would be the perfect way to wrap-up the whole series. We've thought about that since the beginning, doing a movie like that, and it'd be great.‚Äù 

New episodes of ‚ÄúSmiling Friends‚Äù Season 3 air Sunday nights on Adult Swim.

Title: Bruce Springsteen: Nebraska '82: Expanded Edition Album Review
Description:
8.8

 Best New Reissue

Genre:

Rock

Label:

Columbia

Reviewed:

October 24, 2025

Bruce Springsteen was right. At the risk of oversimplifying the merits of this handsome box set, spoiling the plot of his dramatic new biopic, and squashing 40-plus years of fervent mythmaking, the truth is as Springsteen always insisted. Even when testing out the material with his most intuitive collaborators, working with some of the best songs he'd ever written, the definitive version of Nebraska remains the one he captured on tape in his Colts Neck home in January 1982: just a depressive guy in his early 30s with an acoustic guitar, a TASCAM PortaStudio, and an Echoplex, tracking solo demos for his next full-band record. Everything he tried in the following months, as it turns out, was an experiment.

But, lord, what an experiment. For the uninitiated, I'll go through it quickly. After the success of his poppy 1980 single ‚ÄúHungry Heart‚Äù and building off the momentum of several years of nonstop touring and critically acclaimed albums, Springsteen entered the most creatively restless period of his career. First, he wrote the murder ballads and haunted lullabies of Nebraska, which he tried to re-capture with the E Street Band, and in solo renditions in the studio, before deciding to release the home-recorded demos. There was no press and no tour, so he just kept writing, which led to 1984's commercial breakthrough Born in the U.S.A. Along the way, he discarded several records' worth of outtakes that have since been released on compilations like Tracks and Tracks II: The Lost Albums. (He also managed to co-write and co-produce two comeback records for the early rock'n'roll icon Gary U.S. Bonds; contribute a Grammy-winning song to Donna Summer; and put on several pounds of muscle mass.)

It sounds like a golden era, but to Bruce, it felt like a rut‚Äîthe kind of tortured, lonesome period that gets a ceaselessly brooding Jeremy Allen White cast to play you in the film. The irony is that the most important pieces of the puzzle‚Äîfrom the original Nebraska to the lightning-in-a-bottle album version of ‚ÄúBorn in the U.S.A.‚Äù‚Äîall happened quickly, intuitively, before anyone had a chance to overcomplicate things. Like little else in his official catalog, the release of Nebraska 82: Expanded Edition helps contextualize this moment. In a concise package, you get a fuller portrait of one of Springsteen's greatest and most mysterious albums‚Äîand to this day, the one he's proudest of‚Äîas well as candid insight into his creative process.

The box contains a new remaster of the album proper; a disc of solo acoustic outtakes that embody the same wounded spirit; the fabled Electric Nebraska sessions; and a live album and film of Springsteen playing the record in its entirety to an empty theater in New Jersey earlier this year. The live stuff is welcome and fittingly reverential, especially with tasteful accompaniment from former Bob Dylan sideman Larry Campbell. The remaster is solid: a reminder that, despite this album's reputation for helping pioneer the lo-fi genre, the sound is actually more artful and dynamic than much of his work that followed. Next time you listen to ‚ÄúAtlantic City‚Äù on headphones, pay attention to the last 30 seconds, how the layers of acoustic guitar, mandolin, and background vocals slowly dissipate, one at a time, and consider the care that goes into adding such depth to such a stark landscape.

Unlike Springsteen's previous box sets for Darkness on the Edge of Town and The River, the idea isn't to explore how many different directions he could have gone. This time it's a steady process of refinement. Where Nebraska is renowned for a borderline oppressive consistency in tone, Electric Nebraska is all about the whiplash, shifting between heartland ballads and screaming rock songs across the duration of its eight-song tracklist. Presented more like guide tracks than finished takes‚Äîmostly just Springsteen on electric guitar and vocals; Max Weinberg on drums; and Garry Tallant on bass‚Äîthese are the ones that feel like demos, even if they hint at an album that could have been slightly more conventional and commercially viable in 1982. (Although this version of ‚ÄúDownbound Train,‚Äù with its clanging rhythm and disorienting bridge, might go down as the most deranged recording in his catalog.)

It's not hard to see why Springsteen saw these sessions as a failure. There is something slightly generic about the renditions of ‚ÄúOpen All Night‚Äù and ‚ÄúJohnny 99,‚Äù songs I've always associated with desperate, sleep-deprived adrenaline. Here they sound like the kind of things a band could count off and launch into unrehearsed with playful bar-band chords and rockabilly rhythms. On one hand, it shows you just how much Springsteen's writing‚Äîso open to interpretation, so archetypal in its structure‚Äîgains from his delivery. (For another example, compare this bleak, early acoustic take on ‚ÄúThunder Road‚Äù to the triumphant album version.) On the other hand, this type of costuming was crucial to his songwriting during this period: a fascination that could turn a romp like ‚ÄúPink Cadillac‚Äù into something pained and moaning, like the narrator has returned to earth, zombified and broken, with only one thing on his mind.

For hardcore fans, transformations like these will be the draw of the collection: hearing the journey of tracks like Born in the U.S.A.'s ‚ÄúWorking on a Highway‚Äù from a genuinely creepy ballad called ‚ÄúChild Bride‚Äù into a ditty so raucous that Springsteen himself can't get through the demo without laughing. Some outtakes, like ‚ÄúLosin' Kind,‚Äù a country ballad that's all the more powerful for its lack of resolution, have circulated unofficially for years, but two compositions are entirely new to this box set: ‚ÄúOn the Prowl‚Äù and ‚ÄúGun in Every Home.‚Äù In the former, he closes with a disorienting repetition of the word ‚Äúsearching,‚Äù slathered in Sun Studios slapback delay to conjure the clatter of a live band behind him. In the latter, he offers a nightmarish portrait of suburban life and closes with a dejected confession: ‚ÄúI don't know what to do.‚Äù

In any given song, Springsteen may be adopting the perspective of a serial killer in the shadows or a fugitive on the lam; he may be speeding away from the scene or wondering, upon getting caught, whether he is actually lucky to be alive. The whole point of enduring a dark night of the soul is that you can't see your way out. But sometimes, he caught glimpses of where it would lead. Along with the original demo tape, Springsteen wrote an accompanying letter to his manager, Jon Landau. Here, he goes song by song, elaborating on the bleak subject matter, suggesting ways to spice up the arrangements, and, once in a while, acknowledging his cautious optimism.

He leaves a particularly prescient note beside the scrawled title of ‚ÄúBorn in the U.S.A.,‚Äù a song that appears here in two nascent forms: a menacing acoustic blues about Vietnam and a full-band rocker that, without its chiming synth part, leaves little doubt how the narrator feels about his birthright. ‚ÄúMight have potential,‚Äù he writes in the margins, an instinct that sustained him through the sessions. He knew it would take work to deliver songs like these, and it would take time to understand them. But he kept his faith that at the end of every hard-earned day, there's magic in the night.

Title: Cahl Sel: Traces Album Review
Description:
7.9

Genre:

Electronic

Label:

Reflective

Reviewed:

October 24, 2025

Anyone stumbling across the utopian cerulean vistas of Cahl Sel's Blue EP earlier this year could have been forgiven for wondering if the record was a forgotten gem from three decades past, rather than a brand-new production from a young upstart.

For one thing, the label that put it out, Reflective, is itself a vestige of leftfield electronic music's golden age, having lain largely dormant since 1997. Reflective was resurrected in 2022 to release Cahl Sel's debut EP, Every Moment; in its prime, the imprint had been responsible for a wealth of mid-'90s classics‚Äîrecords from bright-eyed mischief-makers like label founder Spacetime Continuum and IDM pioneer ¬µ-Ziq, recording as Kid Spatula, who lured curious ravers in stranger, squirrelier directions. The sound of both Cahl Sel EPs, particularly Blue, invoked that era in their clean-lined drum programming and bucolic washes of synthesizer, and with good reason: The San Francisco musician, aka Jasper Sharp, makes and performs his music on a hardware setup that harkens back to a halcyon, pre-laptop era.

Cahl Sel's debut album, Traces, sounds even more like a lost ambient-techno classic. The drums move like precision-engineered machinery: sturdy yet understated kick drums, die-cutting snares, diamantine hi-hats spinning in tricky clockwork patterns. Arpeggios twirl in elegant arcs against airy pads that glow like a tropical sunrise. Tracing the path of Cahl Sel's serpentine synthesizer melodies, it's easy to imagine hothouse flowers filmed in stop motion: green shoots whipping upward, uncurling in midair, and slowly exploding into star-shaped blossoms tinged with cadmium and azure.

Traces carves a sidewinding path between sleek, propulsive cuts and more atmospheric passages. The jittery techno of opener ‚ÄúBlink‚Äù slows to a languid electro crawl in ‚ÄúCall to Mind‚Äù before the drums disappear completely in ‚ÄúLivin,‚Äù an otherworldly sketch that runs new-age tones through the mazelike circuitry of the BBC Radiophonic Workshop. But, as with the best ambient techno of the '90s, the division between ‚Äúdance music‚Äù and ‚Äúlistening music‚Äù is purely notional: It's a full-body sound that rewards both energetic movement and horizontal repose.

Some of the most energetic tracks are notable largely for what they don't do. ‚ÄúBlink‚Äù begins with spring-loaded claps and hi-hats, but the pads drip down like sun-drenched honey, as if to say, not so fast, tiger; not only that, but there's no bassline, an absence that leaves you hanging in a tantalizing state of perpetual anticipation. Given the speedy tempo and energetic rhythms, you might expect it to evolve into a more forceful club track, yet it never does. Instead, it simply floats in a delirious, delicious interzone.

It's not hard to guess at some of Sharp's influences. Aphex Twin's early work looms large; the mournful ‚ÄúAncient and Distant,‚Äù with its eerie, undulating melody, could easily pass as an outtake from Autechre's Amber. The cozy drone underpinning ‚ÄúLeft Eye‚Äù pulls from the same well from which Boards of Canada drew their fuzzy VHS fantasias. Traces of Burger/Ink's great Las Vegas linger in the intricate counterpoints and dubby undercurrents. And the knife-edged electro patterns look back fondly at Gescom, Bola, and other zero-gravity B-boys affiliated with the Skam label.

But most influential of all might be Spacetime Continuum himself, which probably isn't coincidental: The Reflective chief, aka Jonah Sharp, just happens to be Jasper's father. It's striking how thoroughly Jasper absorbed his dad's vision of electronic music, and it's fun to imagine him as a boy, soaking up his parents' record collection as if by osmosis‚Äîspooning Cheerios while the idyllic sounds of tracks like ‚ÄúPressure‚Äù and ‚ÄúFluresence‚Äù poured from the kitchen speakers. But Cahl Sel's talents are so clearly his own‚Äîjust listen to how masterfully he fans out the stacked harmonies of ‚ÄúClear,‚Äù one of the album's emotional highlights‚Äîthat his parentage should be considered little more than a footnote.

For a similar reason, I hesitate to call his music retro, however much it may resemble its influences. It's certainly no more narrowly retro in its intent than any number of other contemporary electronic projects: From trance to jungle to minimal to dubstep, dance music is awash in throwback energy, and has been for years now. And this kind of wistful ambient techno makes for a special case. The prime years of this sound were awfully short, lasting from the early-mid-'90s until the turn of the millennium. And the canon was so paltry‚Äîonce you've tallied the classics, the dropoff in quality is swift and steep‚Äîthat records like Cahl Sel's read as a kind of wish fulfillment: a belief that there remains more to be done in the genre, and a desire to make good on its untapped potential. Yes, Traces bears ample traces of those who came before him, but Cahl Sel is looking forward, not back.

Title: Florence and the Machine Announce 2026 Tour
Description:
Florence and the Machine have announced the tour in support of their forthcoming album, Everybody Scream. The tour begins in the United Kingdom in February, and, later that month, Florence Welch and her band will head to mainland Europe for more dates. The North American leg begins in April, and support on that leg of the tour will come variously from Rachel Chinouriri, Sofia Isella, CMAT, and Mannequin Pussy. See Florence and the Machine's tour dates below.

Tonight (October 24), Welch will be at the Cherry Lane Theatre for a conversation about her creative process. She'll also play a short acoustic set at the New York venue.

Everybody Scream is Florence and the Machine's follow-up to 2022's Dance Fever. So far, the band has shared the title song and ‚ÄúOne of the Greats.‚Äù The full album is out on October 31.

Title: Megan Thee Stallion Shares New Song ‚ÄúLover Girl‚Äù: Listen
Description:
After dropping ‚ÄúWhenever,‚Äù in April, Megan Thee Stallion has shared her second solo single of the year. ‚ÄúLover Girl‚Äù features a prominent sample of ‚ÄúKissin' You,‚Äù the 1996 R&B hit by Bad Boy girl group Total. Listen to the new song, produced by Jacobdior, below.

Megan Thee Stallion shared her last studio album, Megan, in 2024, following it up with the deluxe expansion Act II a few months later. In January, the Houston rapper was granted a restraining order against Tory Lanez, who is currently serving a 10-year prison sentence after being found guilty of shooting her. Lanez was stabbed in prison in May, prompting Megan Thee Stallion to share a new statement calling out further online harassment she had subsequently received.

Read about Megan Thee Stallion and Cardi B's ‚ÄúWAP‚Äù at No. 22 in ‚ÄúThe 100 Best Songs of the 2020s So Far.‚Äù

Title: Mass MoCA Releases Malawian Roots Album to Launch Its New Label: Listen
Description:
A new album of Malawian roots music is the inaugural release of a new record label from the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art (Mass MoCA). A collaboration with California label Hen House Studios, Mass MoCA Records released the Kasambwe Brothers' self-titled album today, and you can hear it below.

The Kasambwe Brothers are a band of four decades, based in the Ndirande township near Malawian capital Blantyre. They found their way to a Mass MoCA residency with help from Hen House and Luc Deschamps, the director of the Jacaranda Foundation and France's honorary consul to Malawi. Watch a documentary on the making of the album, which involves collaborators from the Massachusetts music scene, below. Clement Kammwamba is the artist behind the cover painting.

Mass MoCA Records will operate in tandem with the museum's curatorial ethos, a press release notes, and is running as a three-year pilot. Museum director Kristy Edmunds said, ‚ÄúBy joining forces with Hen House Studios and being able to tap into the remarkable number of music studios and intimate venues in the local area‚Äîthe ingredients for a hand-made record label were all around us. I see this label as an extension of how we innovate to support the mobility of artists' ideas and connect audiences the world over.‚Äù

Harlan Steinberger, the producer and engineer behind Hen House, added, ‚ÄúThough technology today can work wonders, the digital world has de-humanized us. I believe in an older-world method that emphasizes the magic of a band making music together in one room, playing off the creativity of the moment. The humanistic approach creates a deeper emotional listener experience that can not only be heard, but also felt.‚Äù

An album from Compton jazz artists Black Nile will follow in 2026, the press release notes.

Title: Slash Rules Out a Guns N' Roses Sphere Residency, for Now: It's Not ‚ÄòRock ‚ÄòN' Roll Friendly'
Description:
By 

	Daniel Kreps



Slash has ruled out Guns N' Roses bringing their never-ending reunion tour to Las Vegas' Sphere, saying the state-of-the-art venue isn't ‚Äúrock n' roll friendly.‚Äù


	Speaking with Sirius XM's Trunk Nation, the guitarist was asked about GNR playing the Sphere. ‚ÄúI haven't been [to the Sphere] yet, but just everything that I've seen, or most everything that I've seen of it, looks amazing,‚Äù Slash said (via Blabbermouth). 


	However, ‚ÄúI'm real trepidatious about playing there, because‚Ä¶ It's a great visual show. I think that in almost every case for a band, it becomes a visual show as opposed to seeing a rock n' roll show. So there's that.‚Äù


	Slash added that he talked to Joe Walsh, whose band the Eagles currently resides in the Sphere, about playing the venue, and that the guitarist told him ‚Äúit's not really sort of rock ‚Äòn' roll friendly, the way that it's set up. So it's just one of those things where it seems like a really cool thing, and conceptually there's probably a lot of cool things that you could do, but I don't think it would be the right environment for a proper rock n' roll show.‚Äù

	










			Popular on Rolling Stone		







	Earlier this year, Metallica talked openly about potentially performing at the Sphere. ‚ÄúI'd be interested to see that too,‚Äù Slash said. ‚ÄúI could see them doing it‚Ä¶ You have to prepare your mind to put on not just a band performance, but 50 percent of what you're doing is going to be the projection, or whatever you call that ‚Äî the outer wall, what you're putting on as content.‚Äù

	











	
		Trending Stories
	
	






	
	
		
					Kiss' Gene Simmons, Paul Stanley Mourn Ace Frehley at Funeral Service		
	









	
	
		
					TikTok Can't Get Enough of This Chaotic 4 Non Blondes-Nicki Minaj Remix		
	









	
	
		
					‚ÄòDeliver Me From Nowhere': Fact-Checking the Bruce Springsteen Biopic		
	









	
	
		
					Paul Rodgers Says Bad Company Will Likely Perform at Rock & Roll Hall of Fame		
	









	Despite his trepidation, Slash didn't completely rule out Guns N' Roses occupying the Sphere at some point. ‚Äú[The visuals] is something that's gonna be the main focus of your show and the main focus of what everybody's gonna be looking at,‚Äù Slash told Trunk Nation. ‚ÄúAnd so you have to sort of getting to that mindset, and I think that's hard for us to go that far into it. But we'll see. Maybe down the road.‚Äù


	Earlier this month, the Sphere announced that the reunited No Doubt will be the next act to spend their weekends at the Las Vegas venue, with the band booked for 12 gigs in May 2026.

We want to hear it. Send us a tip using our anonymous form.
